All Reviews

  1. been 4 years and still on the same battery and no cavities ... a great investment ... Hold lightly to the teeth as advised by my dentist

  3. Works better than the older model of SoniCare.
  4. [[VIDEOID:6748ef43ec9adf1b8096721af6b84314]] This is a good news - bad news - good news story of an excellent brush that conked out on me after only 23 months but was still under warranty and quickly replaced by the manufacturer. I would have given it five stars if it had lasted longer. I highly recommend this toothbrush.
  5. I would give it 5 stars because it was wonderful while it worked. I purchased it here in June 2014, and it stopped working 2 days ago (April 17, 2015). I got a whole 10 months out of it. I'm so disappointed because my Elite lasted 7 or 8 years. This thing will no longer hold a charge.
  6. LOVE this tooth brush. I had another Sonicare that died after 4+ years. I was hesitant to spend $$$ to replace it....until I had my 6 month check up at the dentist. Let's just say it was not a great visit. I came home and placed my order immediately! I chose this model because I liked how much cleaner this one was. No plastic cap at the bottom of the brush base where lots of germs and old paste to hide like before. Smaller charging base too. I wasn't sure if these electric toothbrushes were worth it, but now I know they are. $60 on a tooth brush will save me hundreds at the dentist.
  7. This is so much better than my other Sonicare unit which had to be cleaned out several times a week and still wasn't all that clean. This unit doesn't collect gooey stuff and cleans in seconds. I have gingivitis and since using the Sonicare I have been getting perfect reports from my hygienist, gums pink and healthy.
  8. Good toothbrush. The other Philips toothbrush I had, a sophisticated one with lots of useless buttons, started acting up within a year, so it got replaced under its warranty. Then, over a year later, the same thing happened, except this time I had to throw it away. Someone told me that is because if you leave it on the base charging all the time, you mess up the battery. They don't tell you that.<br />So I got this cheaper one, with one button that does exactly the same thing exactly the same way. And now I unplug it once it's charged and almost exhaust the battery before plugging it again to charge.
  9. This is my 2nd one with the 1st costing a little more, But this one is just as good...
  10. It died after 3 years it was good before that. I don't know if they offer a warranty but if they did im sure it's over. Kind of disappointing electronics don't last
  11. We bought this to replace an older model who's battery finally died after 5 years. We wanted to make sure it used the same charger and brushes, and it does. I am happy to say that the new one DOES NOT have the rubber handle that the older one has, which has gotten yellow and mildewed. Otherwise, it's a good replacement.<br /><br />When my husband first insisted that we should buy these expensive toothbrushes because the dentist recommended it, I pooh-poohed the idea. But after he bought his, and I used it a couple of times, I had to have one too. Just makes my teeth feel SO much cleaner than hand-brushing.<br /><br />The rechargable battery lasts a week or two, and our first toothbrush lasted about 5 years. There is a guy on eBay who will replace the battery for you, but our toothbrush looked so ratty after 5 years of hard use that we opted to replace the whole thing.
  12. YES! great design and works well. Super gum stimulation ;+}
  13. Cleans my teeth better than a manual brush, and doesn't have lots of expensive features I didn't need. Dentist recommended this model, and it is a good choice.
  14. I never understood the big deal about an electric toothbrush. That is until I used this one. My dentist recommends brushing teeth for two minutes. Two mins with a manual toothbrush seems like an eternity, but with this model the time flies by. I love the little pause it gives me to let me know that I have spent 30 seconds on a particular area and that its time to move on to the next one. Yes, it vibrates my teeth if I let it touch teeth other than the ones I'm brushing. It's a vibrating toothbrush so that is to be expected. While strange at first, you learn to open your jaws a little more and it minimizes the occurrences. My dental hygienist recommends Philips products and didn't think all the extra bells and whistles were worth the additional expense. This is the model she recommended and now so do I.
  15. I used this model less than a month when the charging light stopped turning off and instead remains on whenever the unit is in its base. When I called Sonicare, the representative gave me the run-around, saying it was not a problem and refusing to give me any explanation about why it happened. I would swear that the unit also slowed down at the same time, now giving a gentle massage instead of a brisk cleaning. I loved my original Sonicare, which I used for years, and I also loved the original brush heads, but I feel cheated by this new model. I am now looking for a different brand of electronic toothbrush.
  16. I love this brush and ask myself every time I use it why it took me so long to get one. I think that it's completely worth the money you pay for (if not on the more inexpensive side) but that's just an added bonus. I do with that the standard brush heads that come with it were more compact in size but if anything I can give them to my dad and he'll have no problem using them. Heads are easily interchangeable and easy to keep clean. Great product and already recommended it to someone for them to replace theirs.
  17. I decided to purchase an electric toothbrush after going to the dentist and needing a lot of work. They had a Sonicare on display so I researched it on Amazon when I got home. Some of the more expensive models have a lot of features I would consider useless such as different speed settings and the UV cleaner. I run my brush head under the faucet with the power on to sonic-shake the germs off it. Seems like it should keep the brush head clean. The one thing I don't like about Sonicare is the fact that it shuts off after two minutes. I feel rushed even though I know I can turn it back on again. I also learned the hard way you have to brush the toothpaste across all your teeth with the power off, then you have to close your mouth around the brush before you turn it on. I splattered toothpaste all over the place the first time I used it. I do feel that is gives a very good cleaning. So far I have only charged it when I first got it and it hasn't needed a recharge in 5 days. I am not crazy about the blinking light during charging. Annoying if you have a master bath within sight and don't want to close the door. The price for the replacement heads seems a little high. If they were less expensive and it didn't shut off automatically, I would have given 5 stars.
  18. I bought this electric toothbrush upon the recommendation of my dentist, and I am not sorry. I have been using an electric toothbrush for years, but they were always heavy and clunky. This one is light and very easy to use. It cleans well and when you are finished your mouth feel fresh and clean. Don't be afraid to try it. Good investment.
  19. just what i needed. great product.
  20. Died on my wife 15 months after we bought it and it appears the warranty is only 12 months on this model. The Phillips warranty return website says I can't return it for a replacement. I've had one of the original Sonicare toothbrushes for over 6 years and have never had a problem. I guess quality control is dead and they know it as they've shortened the warranty period. Avoid.

  24. I had a Sonicare years ago, but it went to its reward after long use. I read a LOT of reviews before purchasing this model. Philips must not be doing well and to compensate is saving money by making these VERY skinny and removing about half the bristles they had before. I figure that in another 10 years they will be selling Sonicares with about 10 bristles. The base is so light that the kink in the cord from being packed twists the unit, making it fall over. I have to prop it up with a heavier object. I absolutely LOVED my original Sonicare, but I consider this one trash. To add insult to injury, I called Philips to see if there were any options with the bristles/brush heads. The rep I spoke with convinced me to buy their deluxe brush heads, claiming they were much better. HAH! Stupidly, I spent more money for brush heads that were the same as this one, just a different color. Guess that would be my fault. As the saying goes, fool me once . . .
  25. Purchased my first about 10 years ago, nothing compares to this toothbrush. Great clean feel and easy on the gums!<br />Highly recommend!
  26. For several years I was using a $5 Crest Spinbrush, which was an improvement over a manual toothbrush, but not by that much. This Sonicare brush is so much better I'm kicking myself for not getting it years ago.<br /><br />The charging stand makes it easy to keep on my very small sink and it's always ready (it cannot become overcharged so you can leave it in the charger at all times). The timer that stops the brush for an instant every 30 seconds so I know to change quadrants of my mouth is very useful; I doubt I was putting in the full two minutes dentists recommend with the Spinbrush. The biggest test for the brush's effectiveness came today after I ate popcorn. Seeds were stuck, including one far back between my last two lower teeth. The very small brush head and powerful strokes effortlessly removed every last bit of food and it was very comfortable even as I worked the very corner of my mouth. No more following brushings with a toothpick to get what lesser brushes won't budge. Considering the cost of dental work, this brush is sure to pay for itself many times over in the long run. Some more expensive models have more bells and whistles, but I feel like this perfectly meets my needs. If I have one nitpick it's that the handle could be non-slip, as my hand starts to slide when water and toothpaste manage to run down it (I open wide to get my teeth as well as possible).<br /><br />If you've never bought an expensive toothbrush, don't let the price spook you, this product is well worth the investment. Besides, Amazon will let you return it if you don't like it so there's no risk.
  27. Liked it so much, bought a second one for my travel bag. Doesn't have all the bells and whistles as their other models, but you don't need them nor will you ever use them. Their other multi-function ones also have a high failure rate unlike this model

  35. Let me tell you a short story. I've never had a cavity in my life. I bought a Sonicare Elite back in 2003, and it was the BEST toothbrush I ever owned. It lasted a good 8 years before the battery would no longer charge, and due to the nature of it, the battery was unable to be replaced. Disappointing, but how could I complain after getting that much use out of it? I decided to \\"upgrade\\" to an Oral B version, the full-blown, gimmicky one with the timer and clock and other whizz-bangs and doo-dads. Now 3+ years later guess what? -- I have a cavity. Yes, I realize it is very unscientific of me to blame it on the Oral B, but you can't deny the fact the other brushes (even the manual ones) were doing something a little better than the Oral B was doing. So, now I've upgraded again, to this toothbrush similar to my original Elite. What a difference! Where have you been? What have I done? I'm sorry I trysted with another, O Philips Sonicare, rest assured I will never stray again! Please forgive me and take me back... EDIT: A few additional observations I'd like to make. The head feels MUCH more nimble and easier to get into the corners of my mouth than the old SoniCare Elite. The handle and stalk is also less bulky. Overall, it's a better design than the previous version. Still loving this brush. What a difference between this and the Oral B! Pair this with a good foaming toothpaste, and you'll love the results just as much.

  40. This is the third Sonicare Brush I've owned. The first two lasted around seven years before starting to lose their brushing vigor. This brush is clearly the best design. The head detaches in a very clever way that prevents water buildup and mold developing. That was the biggest problem I had with the Elite. It is very slender and keeps a charge far longer than any of the other two. At least a month between charges. One tip I learned from the beginning was not to leave the brush on the charger full time - it won't keep its charge as long.<br /><br />The only draw back to this model (and it's very minor) is that it did not come with a travel case. This is the first brush I had that didn't and I always travel with it. The solution for me was to put it in a ziploc since its length prevents me from using it with an older case.<br /><br />Highly recommend this one...I did a lot of research since the models are all so similar.

The fact that I was not using an effective toothbrush and wasn't flossing enough did me in (soda didn't help either). After spending several hours in the dental chair, I decided no matter what, I was never going to do that again. I kissed soda goodbye, bought this new Sonicare toothbrush and committed to flossing every single day - no matter what. It's been over 2 months now and I have kept my commitment to my dental care. I brush 2-3 times per day and floss, even on really late nights. My teeth still feel as clean as they do after a professional cleaning. This toothbrush is not only easier to use than a regular toothbrush, but the timer helps immensely. I don't think I ever brushed for 2 full minutes with a reg brush. I exceed the 2 minutes every time now, just making sure I am thorough. I am extremely satisfied and highly recommend this Sonicare toothbrush.

  68. Having read the description, will a 12-hr.(overnight) charge last a week? I'm a person who bought the original Sonicare and was happy with it - needed to be charged once a week, if that. I bought the Essence mainly because of its larger brush head. It's less than two years old (did not send in the guarantee being told in CA it's not binding) and it needs to be charged at the end of the day after charging up all night. If I had the charger for the previous model, I would throw this one out. Before spending money on a new model, I called the Sonicare number, which was picked up by Sahim, whom I could not hear. He then spoke louder. It's my experience \\"Can you hear me better now?\\" volume will not be maintained throughout the call and I'll be frustrated a minute later, so I said I'd try back, scrolled down at their site to the number at the bottom and spoke to a rep, who told me my experience was the norm with that model - at the same time apologizing! I was told it should be kept in the charger at all times. This is how Detroit screwed up with \\"planned obsolescence\\" and made it easy for their competitors. Not all of us have a bathroom with more than two outlets. If it's not good enough that something charges all night long while I'm not using an outlet and cords are not snared by what's plugged in (and taking up space on a pedestal sink so I barely have access to the faucet) I'll start looking around. I agree with those who say quality control went downhill - engineers are prodded by marketers to screw up a good thing - someone tell these people they're going backward.

I thought about buying another Essence model, but I decided to get a &#34;nicer&#34; and more expensive model. I regret it at this point unless I'm doing something wrong. When I got this Sonicare I charged it for about 12 hours just in case, then I proceeded to brush my teeth as I normally would. I immediately noticed the new Sonicare was not NEARLY as strong as my old Sonicare. It is also much quieter. I thought, &#34;Maybe they've improved on these and made them better?&#34; After I was done brushing my teeth I looked at my teeth and I could tell it did not remove all the plaque that I had on my teeth. I then compared it to my old Sonicare and noticed the vibrations from my old Sonicare are MUCH greater than this new one. I don't know if I got a bad toothbrush or what but it sucks compared to my older one and I'm really disappointed with my purchase. I gave it 3 stars because it does still does its job - just not nearly as well as my old one which makes me want to just go back to using my old one!
  89. I would recommend this tooth brush, the only thing that i don't like about it....is the brush doesn't have a guard on the back of the brush. The previous one that I have does, otherwise it is great.
  90. My wifes overpriced Dentist had been recommending that she purchase a sonic toothbrush that his office sold at, in his words, \\"a lower price than you can find anywhere\\". I called and asked a receptionist to give me the product name and model number and proved the sadistic bastard wrong by simply going to Amazon, finding the product and hitting \\"buy\\".<br />I guess its a good product.   92. I LOVE my Sonicare! My teeth feel so clean, I can't stop running my tongue over them, haha. I use this with Brushing Rinse (sometimes available on Amazon, sometimes on Vitacost), my teeth and gums have never been healthier and my teeth are so white.<br /><br />I Highly recommend this model - more expensive models just have different timing options which I guarantee you'll never (or rarely) use. I used to have a higher end model and I literally never used any other mode. I haven't tried it yet but I bought the Diamond Clean brush heads to use with this model, I read that they are compatible but I'll update this review for sure when I try it out. The brush heads make a way bigger difference than the model of the toothbrush, I recommend you spend your money on those instead.<br /><br />You're dentist will be able to tell that you are using a Sonicare, that's how good they are!
  93. The Philips Sonicare Hx6511/50 Easy Clean Rechargeable Toothbrush is an excellent value at Amazon.com. I bought this for my wife after having one myself for several years. You actually feel the clean. One needs to try it to understand what they mean when they say you can feel the sonic care clean. Your teeth feel clean. However, just remember the first few times it will feel \\"weird\\" my wife said it tickled. You will get a hold of how to hold and use the brush to avoid that feeling. This model for the price offers the best value. Plus at amazon, you can't go wrong.
  94. The product worked great but completely died after just over a year. I will try another one but if it has a similar lifespan, that will be the last.
  95. I've had my Sonicare toothbrush for a month now and I have to say that I like it. This is my first electric toothbrush. I chose this brand because of the heads. The Oral B toothbrushes all have that circular brush head or the dual-moving head. I tried out both on my boyfriend's Oral B brush and I didn't like them. I like the Sonicare much better because it feels more like a regular toothbrush. It is easier to cover all of the tooth surfaces, especially far back in the mouth. This toothbrush isn't bulky like many other electric toothbrushes. It is light and slender. It's easy to clean, just pop the head off and rinse. When I first got it I charged it for 24 hours. I've been using it every day for a month and I haven't had to charge it again yet. The \\"travel case and cap\\" that it comes with is just a cheap plastic cover for the actual brush part, so don't be fooled into thinking you're getting an actual case for the entire brush. The Quadpacer is nice, just a small pause in the vibration every 30 seconds to let you know to move to the next quadrant. I do wish that it didn't turn off automatically after the 2 minutes because I often like to go back and hit the important spots one more time. Also, the Easy-Start ramping up period over the first 2 weeks is a great way to get used to the brush without your gums being aggravated. Overall, I like the toothbrush. My mouth feels cleaner and stays cleaner longer than it does with a regular toothbrush. I can't say that I've noticed any whitening of my teeth like I had hoped, but there is still time. I would definitely recommend it.
  96. My dentist recommended this style toothbrush becuase it's gentler on the gums. A little over a year ago I bought one of the more expensive Sonicare models and it broke after about a year. Further, I was always pushing the extra buttons on the more expensive model while holding the toothbrush. The more expensive model broke after a year and even though I think that's too short of a lifespan, I decided to get another Sonicare anyway. This model is perfect. It's cheaper, and doesn't have any of the unnecessary bells & whistles. I don't expect this model to last much longer than the previous one, but functionally it's great.
  97. I absolutely love this thing! It really cleans your teeth well and holds a charge for a really long time.

  103. I bought this to replace my old Sonicare Elite, which died after many years of good service. That one came with a little stand to hold a pair of heads, for two users. A standard size and a compact size brush head fit the handle; my husband used the standard, and I, being small, the compact size. Every day, twice or more often per day, we would each switch to our personal brush head and when finished brushing, place it back in the stand. It was very simple to screw the heads on and off. This version came with no such stand, and while the system makes cleaning easy, it clearly is not designed in contemplation of several-times daily switching of heads - the heads take a little bit of effort to remove and re-attach -- nothing burdensome, but not the swift deal that the prior version entailed. I wonder how the handle and the heads will stand up to three months of repeated pulling off and pushing on, 4 or more times a day. It seems as though the manufacturer intended for each user to have his or her own handle - and the price of a single one is considerably higher than the approximately $30 I paid for the original that served us both. Does Philips hope we will buy a separate toothbrush with handle for every member of the family? Also, there appear to be no compact brush heads for this model- I am stuck with the too- big- for- my-petite-mouth standard brush head - unless I want to use the one designed for gums, which is small but not the right head for tooth brushing... Philips does make a compact head but not for this handle..

Regardless, it feels great... August 2016 Update: A year and one month after I bought this, the unit died. I went to the amazon page and saw the phone number for Philips customer service. I called and got a replacement handle within one day. It was such a delight! But worked for one day... I called Philips again, explained the problem and told them in my opinion it's not the handle that's the problem, it's that the base stopped working. The customer service rep said she couldn't send a new base, so i waited and waited. This time the new handle took a week and a half to get here. No matter, I got my new handle, it worked great - for ONE day. I called them again and this time insisted they send me a base. We'll see.. I'll be back to update y'all. August 21, 2016 - guess what? the base didn't work...I called to let them know it didn't work at all, and the customer service rep - oh, no problem, we'll send you another charger... I said NO. I am now without my toothbrush for five weeks. This is ridiculous, for a tooth brush that cost $70, is supposed to last two years and lasted only one? NO, I need you to send me a whole new, brand new in the box retail unit. Charger and handle and top. She said couldn't do that, so i asked to speak to a supervisor. None was available. She asked to put me on hold, put me on hold and STILL couldn't get a supervisor. She said she'll get back to me, and never did. I called again today, spoke to a very nice young man by the name of Cody. They can't send a whole new unit because they don't have one in their parts department (huh??) so i said, fine, refund half the purchase price and i'll buy something else. he updated me that their escalation team is handling it and will get back to me.... I'll keep y'all posted :)

  111. I think the product does a nice job cleaning teeth, but my Sonicare became so noisy over a months period that I'm returning it for a new one. In my case, the brush head fitting became so loose that it kept falling off. I replaced it with the other brush head that was provided but the product was still very loud and the vibration was still a lot more intense than when I first received the product. There are two issues I see with this item: first, the body doesn't seem to have very durable dampeners within so the item begins to vibrate intensively; second, after tacking the brush off the body several times to clean it, the fit of the brush on the metal pin loses its tightness, so the head begins to magnify the vibration - major tooth chipping potential. I've noticed only a few reviews complaining about noise or vibration issues, so maybe I received a bad model. Hopefully, the replacement will not have the same issue.
  112. This toothbrush does a good job of cleaning teeth. It takes up little counter space because of the compact charging unit. As received, no brush was included in the package. This was very fair of Amazon because the lack of a brush in the factory-sealed container was not Amazon's fault.   122. Packaging is minimalist, akin to receiving the new Apple products. Owning a Philips medical device is very exciting, especially when their next up apparatus likely costs over 10x is sold through the buy-you-lunch sales reps types. I rotated the box just long enough to see it contained what I've been waiting for: the single post / screw-less brush head design. This is my 4th Sonicare toothbrush, having tried most every model since introduction due to dadDDS. I can say they operate identically. My dad frequently commented on my previous bristle brush hygiene always gave his hygienist extra work, until a few months later after using the bulky original non-pacer Sonicare everything was improved at a time I was eating lots of popcorn and sodas (high school). I hardly use bristle brushes when I'm without my Sonicare, preferring to spend 20 minutes with a few peppermint flavored birch toothpicks; the kind that eventually fray flat for good surface scrubbing. For every Sonicare model I have owned before this one, I would actually skip brushing because the black bacteria would gross me out enough to not want it in my mouth. I really hope the fix for easy cleaning has been made. Again, every other Sonicare models other than this one require a screw tight fit which isn't so tight after a few rings of dried bacteria form on the threads. This led to greatly noticeable reduction in action intensity, sometimes over days time. When you finally catch it, it tells you the gentle action of the last few days was not battery or your stronger gums, but layers of dried bacteria (even with the Philips Sonicare UV Station) non-noticeably rattling the whole mouthpiece. Single pole, single hole, single seal. Simple. I hope I'll be using this one until battery death (then I'll erase all this and complain about the battery :)

  147. Phillips EasyClean electric toothbrush seems to be the answer to all the negative comments I've read about other electric toothbrushes.   148. I bought one of these a couple of years ago at the suggestion of my dentist since I tend to build up plaque quickly on my teeth. After using this toothbrush for a couple of years I have not only felt the difference versus using a manual toothbrush, but I ended up having much better checkups during my dentist visits. The two minute interval (30 second for each quadrant) takes out all the guess work in having to brush for 2 minutes. The toothbrush does an excellent job in breaking up plaque and cleaning in areas that a normal toothbrush simply can't get to,<br /><br />However after a couple of years of use, the toothbrush no longer charges when sitting on the base all night. The toothbrush would shut off long before the two minutes is up and recently it won't even stay on for 10 seconds. I figured the battery needed to be replaced, but imagine my disappointment when I found out that this cannot be done because this toothbrush was designed in such a way that you can't simply replace a battery. In other words after a couple of years or so you are left with a useless piece of equipment that you simply have to throw away. I don't know how much anyone else spent on this toothbrush but for the amount I spent I think its ridiculous that I can't simply replace a battery to keep on using it. Apparently Philips wants you to go out and buy another Sonicare every two years instead of designing their products so customers can simply replace a bad battery so they can continue to use what they already have Sorry, but I don't like throwing my money away like that and while I did like the performance of the Sonicare I refuse to purchase from a company that forces its consumers to purchase new products due to planned obsolescence.<br /><br />I will not go back to using a manual toothbrush, but the next electronic toothbrush I buy won't be from Philips.<br /><br />Great toothbrush, not so great design.

  154. I've used a Sonicare toothbrush since the original model appeared on infomercials in the 1990s. This model is my 3rd. Each model has worked well and lasted for years. I expect this to do the same. I find this to be a great improvement over my prior models for a few reasons. First, the size is great. The handle is half the size of my previous models. That means it's lighter and more comfortable to hold than previous models. In spite of the smaller size, the battery life is better. I just had to recharge mine for the first time after using for at about 5 or 6 weeks. That means once it's at full charge, I can put the charger away and not have it cluttering up space. It also means that when traveling I can leave the charger behind for most trips. Also, there's a light on the power button that blinks when power is getting low so you know when to pull out the charger. Finally, this is more powerful than my previous models. Another reviewer said this was not as powerful and insisted he did not have the Easy-start feature activated. I find that hard to believe. I can't imagine a Sonicare with more power. (And I do recommend you leave the Easy-start feature on if you're not used to Sonicare.) Improved in every way. Very happy. Highly recommended.
  155. I hardly take the time to write reviews of things I've purchased but this toothbrush is awesome.   160. I love the timer which indicates 30 second increments. That way you can brush each row of teeth for the same amount of time.
  161. The basic Sonicare is excellent. It cleans better overall than the original design (particularly the back molars). Also, the handle is lighter, and the charger compact.<br /><br />I would not pay more (let alone twice) for any of the \\"advanced\\" versions. They clean in exactly the same way as the basic model (same brush, motor, charger), but have options that are largely useless.<br /><br />About the options: (a) For a softer mode, a manual brush with extra-soft bristles (like the Nimbus) is more effective and gentler on the gums, (b) for a \\"deeper\\" mode (just more time), press the button twice instead, and (c) the UV system to \\"sanitize\\" the head by killing bacteria is useless, and provides no real health benefit compared to rinsing the brush.
  162. It is quiet compared to the OralB I had been using. It vibrates, pulsates and moves at high frequency as the videos you can see online show, Philips calls it Sonic. Every 30 seconds there is a brief pause and noise to tell you to move on to the next quarter of your teeth. After two minutes it shuts off. You get used to all of the above pretty quickly. Battery life seems long (no recollection of excessive charging). The handle/brush are long enough to get to the back teeth without any problems. The brush itself is small enough to get around to all areas. Short term quality has been good, long term is to be determined. But, if you register Philips gives you 2 1/2 years warranty which seems generous. Clearly an upgrade from the $15-20 OralB electric toothbrush it is replacing. Lightyears ahead of a manual toothbrush. If you are in the market for a \\"high end electric toothbrush\\" seems the two real decisions are - how many bells and whistles do you want to pay for and do you go Philips or OralB. I wanted to go a step above the back and forth or round and round electric toothbrushes but didn't want to pay for all the bells and whistles that really don't help your teeth or gums. This model seems like a happy medium point. On the Philips/OralB decision, have always used the less expensive ones from OralB because of the toothbrush itself. At the higher end, one trusts the toothbrush itself on the OralB and Philips is a wash. Philips seemed to me to have more experience and more research into the mechanics at this price point and that tilted me toward the Sonicare. Would make the same decision today after using it. All in all, nothing not to like. I would recommend this Sonicare to anyone looking.
  163. I used to have an older model Sonicare that lasted me almost six years. It would still work, but was falling apart, so my wife bought me this model. I really liked this model and felt the design was an improvement. However after three months, the toothbrush quit charging. I called Sonicare for a replacement toothbrush and charger, but they said they were required to only provide the base first and if that wouldn't work they would send the toothbrush. 10 business days later I got the base, and the toothbrush still wouldn't charge. I called again and was told a toothbrush would be sent to me, but they didn't have anything in stock and there was no timetable they could give me. That makes me suspicious about what is happening at Sonicare - are quality issues the reason they are out of stock? From having to replace so many toothbrushes? Is it just a bad model and they are not stocking it anymore?<br /><br />I haven't received any answers and am still waiting to hear back from them as to what they will do. Needless to say, I am disappointed.
  164. Upgraded from older model used for over 5 years, so far so good. Overall happy with purchase, no cons I can think of. Researched other models, this one fell in the mid-range sweet spot for price and features. Really light, powerful, good battery life, what's not to like?
  165. My dentist recommended Philips Sonicare toothbrushes for better oral care than conventional toothbrushes. So far, so good. No cavities on my latest check-up.   171. I have used Philips Sonicare elect. toothbrushes for years. This is the first toothbrush of theirs that solves my problems with the other designs. This EasyClean 500 Series has a slim compact handle--slimmer than any of the others I have used. Love it! And the best design change they made is the easy-to-clean attachment of the brush head to the handle. The brush head has a very small attachment connecting mechanism: simply a very small recess in the bottom of the brush head component that pushes onto a slim metal rod in the handle. Finally no cavities to harbor mold, grim, old toothpaste, saliva, etc. I was shocked and disgusted when I pried open the insides of my old brush head bottom--I had to use a screw driver to pop off a plastic disc up inside the old brush attachment. They should have made these changes years ago!
  172. My teeth feel really, really clean after I use this! This is a great toothbrush. Works wonderfully! I am so glad I got this.
  173. Easy. There is only one button. It rests every 30 seconds to alert you to change the quadrant of your mouth. Does exactly what it is supposed to.

No fancy case, a basic charging stand, and what I see as a bonus - no special cleaning modes or timing modes - which are useless and get activated too easily by an extra button on the handle. I got 2 for the price of 1 of the highest end models.

A feature i love is the timer that tells you when to move from one area of your mouth to the next, it automatically shuts off when the 2 minutes are up.   178. This is my third Sonicare toothbrush and I don't think there's anything that'll make me switch toothbrushes. My dentist originally recommended Sonicare nearly 15 years ago. I like this stlye, Easy Clean, better than my two previous ones. It's light and thin, easy to hold and easy to maneuver around in my mouth. The 15 second pauses are more valuable than you would think, helps keep you focused in one area until it's time to move on. The on/off switch takes little pressure which is helpful for me as I occasionally have pain in my knuckles that can make pressing buttons difficult. I usually take a traditional toothbrush when I travel and really don't feel like I'm getting my teeth as clean as they should be, but I'm going to take it on an upcoming 5-day trip and test out the guaranty of a 2-week charge. Highly recommend this brush!

I couldn't use this brush as I thought I could, and Amazon was amazing in helping me get a refund. I love Sonicare and this is the third Sonicare we've had thru the years, all the previous models had twist-on heads, which made switching them out very quick and easy. This model has a snap-on head which is really, really, really tough to get off, definitely not meant to be switched out multiple times a day for multiple users. Other than that, this is a great upgrade from our last Sonicare--having a snap-on head means you don't get \\"gunk\\" growing inside the handle where the heads twist on and off. If you're going to use this as a couple or family, you'll need to buy multiple handles. After using Sonicare for years I can not stand using a manual toothbrush, the difference is stunning in how clean your teeth feel and general teeth/gum health. Thanks again AMAZON!!

  227. Great electric toothbrush for the &#34;shower toothbrusher&#34;. In purchasing this I wasn't quite sure how it would work out as I prefer to brush my teeth in the shower in the morning, and obviously having any type of electric device in the shower can be risky. However, I have had this brush for about a week now, brushing in the shower every morning, and I have had no problems. It should be noted that both the charging base and the female charging connector on the toothbrush are both solid plastic. So you don't have to worry about water/corrosion effecting the charging connection. How they're able to charge using plastic on plastic, I don't know - but it works! Otherwise, the brush itself seems to be working quite nicely. It does take a little getting used to as the vibration can give an almost &#34;tickling&#34; type feeling for the first couple uses. I personally adjusted to that after a couple days. The brush head is a little on the small side, which I think helps to work in the harder-to-reach areas of your mouth. All in all, so far it has proven to be a nice electric toothbrush!

  289. At my last cleaning the dental hygienist, a new girl, convinced me into buying a Sonicare. She had a Flexcare model to show and gave me a $10 coupon as well. Sonicare has allot of models which seems overwhelming until you do a little research. It comes down to this, there's the old style brush heads and then there's new style. The newer models range from EasyClean to DiamondClean. They are all basically the same except for bells and whistles. The different power settings are just different time settings. Higher models offer more LEDs and fancier bases.<br /><br />I've used the brush for about 3 weeks now and am very happy with it. Sonicare claims whiter teeth. Mine are coffee stained, but it has actually lightened up a shade. I have an old cap and my natural teeth are actually trending back towards my cap color which was the color of my teeth a long time ago. My teeth feel cleaner to.<br /><br />OK, now for the buying experience. I love Amazon and I love their Prime service, but they dropped the ball on this one. My new toy arrived in two days nicely packed just like Christmas. When I opened the box is was immediately obvious that the toothbrush had been opened. Sonicare closes their box with a clear tamper proof sticker. Someone had carefully opened and resealed it. It gets worse. Upon inspection everything was there, the handle vibrated good and the charger worked. Unfortunately the brush head's plastic bag had been torn open. I can only assume someone tried it and decided to return it. Uuugh.<br /><br />Of course being Amazon returns are easy, but that's the problem. Amazon, this is a hygiene product. You can't just restock returns.
  290. Owned many other electric toothbrushes with limited success. Mostly the others claim to clean and do not in everyday practice. The Phillip Sonicare is pricey, but it really works. There are a number of brush heads to fit personal preference and cleaning needs. Follow the instructions regarding time to clean each 'quadrant' and the results in the product claims are realized. It's rare these days to have a product meet the manufacturers claims, and this toothbrush does. If you want to have teeth that look, feel and are clean, get this line of Sonicare toothbrush (there are other Sonicare toothbrushes of the same design with more bells and whistles such as the Philips Sonicare Flexcare Rechargeable Electric Toothbrush).

I probably get only 8 weeks use at best before the 'reminder bristles' fade to the point where Sonicare recommends replacement. That's why I gave this product four stars rather than five. The price here at Amazon is much better than what I've been able to find in stores.<br /><br />A couple of years ago my dentist told me that generally speaking, he sees a 30% improvement in gum health for people who purchase this product. My experience backs this up. Just yesterday, my hygienist remarked (without prompting) that she always sees an improvement in patients' teeth when they use an electric brush. (no product name from her)<br /><br />I use the 'standard size' brush head and I believe my teeth are being cleaned better than ever before. In addition to the Sonicare motion, the cut and angle of the bristles are probably the difference makers. I would not recommend the compact version of this brush as it does not have the same bristle configuration and lasts even less time than the standard size brush.<br /><br />The brush heads are not cheap so be prepared to spend $$ for replacements. Amazon has the best prices for those too. Whatever you do, don't go for 'off brand' replacement heads promoted by some online deal brokers. I tried those and though they 'looked' the same as the Philips brand heads, they were horrible. Some didn't even fit and kept coming off and the longest use I got from any of those was probably 1 week before they started to come off in my mouth. I could go on and on about those things.<br /><br />Bottom line, if you want to Really take care of your oral health, this toothbrush is great!eat!

  338. The Philips Sonicare EasyClean and similar Sonicare models (the ones with the slim handles) are now better than Oral-B for international travel (including 220V European and Asian countries) for two reasons.<br /><br />1) THE PHILIPS SONICARE EASYCLEAN INCLUDES A UNIVERSAL VOLTAGE CHARGER (FOR BRUSHES SOLD IN USA), ORAL-B DOES NOT ANYMORE<br />The Sonicare EasyClean (and its slim-handled Sonicare cousins) include a dual voltage / universal voltage charger*, but Oral-B no longer does. (There is an Oral-B dual voltage charger that is -supposedly- sold separately but it is impossible to find. Perhaps Oral-B no longer makes it.)<br /><br />*Despite selling the SAME EasyClean brush (HX6511/50) in other countries, a dual voltage charger is NOT always included in non-US markets - instead a single voltage charger sometimes is! To make matters worse, the dual voltage charger and single voltage charger have the same appearance and the same model number: HX6100. The only way to distinguish between them is to check the voltage label, which is displayed on the bottom of the charger. You need to turn the charger upside down to see it. I wish Philips / Sonicare would stop this practice and be consistent across all countries.<br /><br />2) THE PHILIPS SONICARE EASYCLEAN HAS A PHENOMENAL 3 WEEK BATTERY LIFE, WHILE ORAL-B BRUSHES = 10 DAYS AT MOST<br />The Sonicare EasyClean's 3 week battery life (brushing 2x daily) is also superior to Oral-B's and therefore another reason that Sonicare is better for international travel.

  341. This is my first electric toothbrush and I must say that I love this unit. The function that I find most useful is the two minute timer. It alerts you via vibration after thirty seconds that it's time to move onto another section of your teeth. As per the manual, I like to brush thirty seconds in the front of my top teeth, thirty in the back, thirty in the front of my bottom teeth, and thirty in the back. It's such a simple function and yet it has made brushing my teeth less of a chore. I love it and I'm sure my teeth love it as well.<br /><br />This EasyClean model also lives up to its name. The toothbrush head is easily detachable and easily cleaned. I usually clean it after two or three uses but generally it should be cleaned after every use to prevent any buildup.

  349. Clean very well, but last only 7months of use (2 times/day)<br /><br />This is so far the most expensive toothbrush I have ever bought. I love the clean feeling after use and I cannot live without it. Sadly the unit stopped taking charge and would randomly start on and off by it own. I did a little research and people said moisture might have gotten inside to the inside circuit board and caused a malfunction. They would recommend to remove the base with a flat head screwdriver and blow dry it. OK, I did that and upon opening the base, I realized there were 2 tiny copper wires that connect the base cap directly to the circuit board, as a result (it worked like a trap!!!), they broke. As you can see, there were a lot moisture got trapped inside the unit (I always wiped clean and dried the unit after every use, this thing is an expensive toothbrush!).<br /><br />This unit was sealed pretty good from outside, there would be no impossible way to get in and blow dry the inside on a daily basis(you would think it should be sealed and stayed dry inside, but no). This is more like a design flaw, moisture got in and could not get out, tiny wires connect directly to the opening cap....<br /><br />I will not waste $70 again on a toothbrush that can last only half a year. I still have 2 refill heads and not sure what to do with it. May be I will use them as ordinary toothbrush, lol

The replacement heads are 30$ for a pack of two (unless you find some manufacturer coupon). It's an investment, but I've seen the different in my teeth: less stains, less plaque, minimal tartar build up and extremely healthier gums. To be honest, my teeth never felt cleaner, even after cleanings at the dentist! I can't imagine going back to using a regular toothbrush ever again.   432. My Oral B toothbrush battery stopped holding a charge after several years of use. After Google searching the pros and cons of Oral B vs. Sonicare, I decided more or less on the spur of the moment to try out the Sonicare. Some of my comments:<br /><br />The Sonicare does not have any rubber grip on the case (the Oral B does have a textured rubber grip). The rubber grip on my Oral B would get dirty with toothpaste residue and was hard to clean and keep sanitary. The smooth plastic of the Sonicare is a bit more slippery, but far easier to keep clean.<br /><br />I find the vibrating action of the Sonicare to be just as effective as the mechanical action of the Oral B. My teeth feel just as clean, but I feel as though it is gentler on my gums. The Oral B was quite harsh, and I personally avoided letting it touch my gums. Not a big deal if the Sonicare brush touches my gums, it is quite gentle once you get used to it.<br /><br />The Sonicare timer pulses every thirty seconds and shuts off after 2 minutes. This is supposed to signal you to brush each quadrant of your mouth for 30 seconds. I don't personally brush that way, but I find the thirty second reminders encouraging to help me brush for the whole 2 minutes as recommended.

  448. I have been using electronic toothbrushes for nearly 20 years now. Most of the models I have used have performed to a high enough standard to leave me not wishing to use a regular manual toothbrush anymore.<br />Philips' Sonicare however, is a considerable improvement in a few ways over the Oral B models I have used. What I like most of all is the how much fresher my mouth feels after the toothbrush does it's job. The effort required by the user is very minimal. As the manual suggests; guiding the toothbrush slowly, instead of actual scrubbing is all that is required for desired results in only two minutes.<br /><br />I also like the slimness the body of the motor unit. Previous models have been wide enough to result in occasional collisions with front teeth when reaching rear teeth.<br /><br />The stock bristles are very comfortable. As good as I have encountered over the years.<br /><br />The charge time isn't much of an improvement over what I am used to. Up to 24 hours is normal for a full charge from an almost completely drained battery. The good news is, I went three weeks before I needed to recharge the HX6511/50. I have found the battery on almost everything rechargeable does do better in the long run when a full, uninterrupted charge is provided every time.<br /><br />Very low maintenance is required. Keeping the brush, the replaceable head and the charging station clean is easy. A rinse of the head and motor body after every use is worthwhile. Wiping-down the charging base whenever it appears anything less than clean with a multipurpose cleaner has always worked well for me.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1. Very minimal motor vibration.<br />2. Teeth-hugging bristles<br />3. Impressive ergonomics. Good fit in the palm and easy to guide.<br />4. Green LED instead of blue. Much more subtle in the dark at night.<br />5. Leaves mouth feeling very fresh.<br />6. Price.<br />7. Convenient when traveling - dual voltage and 50/60Hz. Charges just about anywhere offering electricity (socket fitment adapter may still be required).<br />8. On/off button is easy to access, but not where you are likely to keep accidentally switching it off.<br /><br />Cons:<br />1. Charge time no worse than the competition, but it doesn't seem to have improved in 20 years.<br />2. Power cord takes a couple of weeks to soften. Results in the base requiring basic support during charging to avoid falling-over.<br />3. Open with care to avoid packaging cuts.<br /><br />Overall, I am very pleased with my purchase. Philips are offering a very well thought-out design here which works very effectively. Not many bells and whistles are on board (quite normal at it's price point), but it has everything to get your mouth feeling fresh within two minutes. And it does so without feeling as though it is applying too much pressure or excess scrubbing to teeth and gums.
  449. My teeth have literally never been so clean. I also love how small the brush head is because it reaches all the way back to my back molars. We've had ours for 3 months and it's still running like a champ. Love it. Worth the investment.

  463. What can I say? It's strong, convenient, and its small enough for my mouth.<br />Totally worth the money! Highly recommend.
  464. Based on other reviews I've read I guess I'm in the minority, but compared to my older Sonicare Elite e7300, this toothbrush is a disappointment. It may be sleeker looking, easier to clean and lighter weight, but it has nowhere near the cleaning power of the older Elite models. If you compare the two, it becomes immediately obvious that Phillips is attempting to capitalize on the reputation of their original Sonicare, while lowering the quality and increasing their profits.<br /><br />Their description points out that the brush \\"cleans with up to 31,000 movements per minute\\", the same as the original Elite model. What they don't tell you is that each up & down movement (sweep) of the brush is much shorter and as a result, nowhere near as effective. It is also far less powerful. If you apply even a moderate amount of pressure to the bush, it will stop oscillating. It still makes noise, lots of it, but it doesn't provide any brushing action.<br /><br />Also interesting to note is the fact that the suggested retail price of the replacement heads is nearly identical to that of the older model, although they are not nearly as complex, or costly to manufacture. At nearly $13 / head (MSRP), Phillips could afford to give away the toothbrushes and still make a profit! The new series brushes aren't much more complex than a standard manual toothbrush! In fact, it is the redesign of the brush heads that make the newer Sonicare HX series so much less effective.<br /><br />!!!Tech Alert - If tech stuff bores you then stop reading now!!!<br /><br />The original heads contained a powerful magnet that was affixed directly to the brush. When you turned the toothbrush on, an electromagnetic signal was generated within the handle that caused the magnet, and therefore the brush, to vibrate.<br /><br />This is virtually identical to the way a permanent magnet speaker works. In a speaker, the permanent magnet is attached to the speaker cone and moves back and forth in proximityto a fixed voice coil. When an audio signal is applied to the voice coil (from an audio amplifier), the magnet attached to the cone moves back and forth, generating sound. The more signal that's applied, the louder the sound. In the case of the original Sonicare Elite, the brush head acted like the speaker cone and the voice coil was contained in the handle. The handle also contained an amplifier along with an ultrasonic oscillator tuned to 31 KHz. All in all, an ingenious design.<br /><br />Due to its larger size, the older Elite model could contain a more powerful amplifier and I suspect larger batteries to support it. The unique head design, with the magnet attached directly to the bush, produce a longer throw (sweep) of the bristles, resulting in more thorough brushing. In addition, due to the powerful magnet attached to the head and the more powerful amplifier, it was nearly impossible to stall the original Elite models, no matter how hard you brushed.<br /><br />!!!End Tech Alert!!!<br /><br />In the case of the new HX series brushes, it's clear that form (and profit) won over function. The new brushes may be more ergonomic, easier to care for and lighter weight, but when it comes to cleaning teeth, they're no where near as effective and it seems to me that's what you buy a toothbrush for, to clean teeth!
  465. I had one of these several years ago when I was young and lost it. Bought it and have been using it since January 2014. It's REALLY great. It makes my teeth noticeably cleaner, but it's also been awesome for my gums. This is the first time I've gone to the dentist where they didn't say I had inflamed gums and when I told them I was using a Sonicare they sad that's probably why. This is totally worth the purchase.
  466. It's very useful to teeth, and I like that soft feeling. The battery can use a long time, so awesome!
  467. After the initial &#34;tickle&#34;, it is a pleasure to brush. My teeth certainly feel cleaner and most assuredly are cleaner. The battery seems to hold a charge longer than my old electric brush. My dentist will be happy. I would recommend this product to a friend.
  468. Keep buying these and then keep throwing them away after they stop recharging. Might be a year, might be a little more or less. But I've bought about 5. Not again. Switching to the Health product and we will see how that does.
  469. I accidentally ordered this toothbrush. It's good but not as powerful as I thought it would be. I kept it and use it but wished it had been a little more powerful.
  470. Very nice tooth brush. Easy and comfortable to use and keep clean. My teeth feel cleaner than when using a regular tooth brush. I been using it for about five months.
  471. Cleans like crazy. Just be prepared for the oddest sensation on your gums for the first week. Even though I previously used an OralB, the 'sonic' speed of this brush makes for a different experience. You do get used it so don't worry about that. It's not an unpleasant feeling either. More of a tickle than anything.
  472. Does a great job cleaning teeth. Replacement heads are more expensive than a new toothbrush but teeth are much cleaner using this.
  473. I had the Oral-B Triumph for a few years and while the Oral-B's head is a better shape for your mouth, the action of the Sonicare is far better and gives my mouth a cleaner feel. Both will get the job done, but I'll be sticking with Sonicare in the future.
  474. I have a Healthy White model from about two years ago and when the brush head is pulled off the soft gasket material at the base is black with mildew. I could not really afford a better model and doing some research found I did not have to spend the money. The Pro Brush that comes standard with this says it removes 2X the plaque of a manual toothbrush. You do NOT have to buy a more expensive model - just buy the better brush heads. Almost all of the available brush heads fit this model except Essence of course. The Diamond Clean and the Interdental brush heads claim to remove 7X as much plaque as manual brushing so if you want a better clean - just buy different brush heads. They recommend changing brushes every 3 months but I brush 2x a day and can go longer. I have gingivitis due to dry mouth from illness and medications and using the Sonicare has made a HUGE difference in my oral health. My purchase came with a $ 4.00 coupon towards brush heads and $ 26. in other Sonicare items.<br /><br />There is a 14 day ramp up feature for those who are nervous about switching from a manual - the intensity starts out very gently and gradually increases.<br /><br />I do NOT understand why it is called Easy Clean because it has exactly the same attachment as my Healthy White. It can be a bit of a pain to get off BUT I recommend removing at least every couple of days so it can dry out fully.<br /><br />This is a FANTASTIC product and you will not regret buying it.
  475. I purchased this on a whim for something new to try out. I love it! The vibrations tickled my mouth at first but after a couple times using it I got used to it. It actually feels really good. After I brush my teeth with this they feel very clean. It is a nice sleek design and the charging stand hardly takes up any space at all. The price I paid on amazing was about $20 cheaper than what I saw the exact same product for at Target so I would highly recommend getting it from Amazon.
  476. this is our third or fourth sonicare in about 15 years. we love them. this one is much better than the e-series we've had in the past. glad to not have to screw on brush heads but rather slide them on the metal post. we did not have the issues of gunk build up at the bottom of the heads as some mention but we were careful to wipe them after each use so maybe that helped. i would highly recommend using this model. i'm not a big fan of the quad notification but for the feeling of how clean these things leave your teeth, it is worth it. i do like the smaller handle. it is much lighter than the e-series and easy to move in your mouth. we've had our about 3-4 months now and it works great. i'm curious to see how long the life of the battery is on these newer models. Our first one lasted at least 5 or more years.
  477. After the first replacement head i tried to place, the product base broke and was making a loud noise and not functioning properly. Very impressive.

  481. This review will compare the Sonicare to the Cybersonic II, even though the Cybersonic II is not available. Reason? Because I'm thinking many people bought them about the time I did and are now looking for a substitute, since the Cybersonic 3 is almost identical to the original model and reviews say it doesn't last long. My Cybersonics lasted about 6 years each.<br /><br />Reasons the Sonicare is better:<br />1. Faster motion means more scrubs per minute<br />2. Smaller brush head fits easily in gaps where teeth are missing and gets deeper between normal teeth.<br />3. A little smaller and lighter<br />4. Metal spindle and interface between handle and brush. The Cybersonic has a plastic interface that wears out quickly if you have a family snapping brushes and flossers in and out daily.<br /><br />Reasons the Cybersonic II was better:<br />1, Has a very, very good flossing system included... the best I've ever seen<br />2. Bigger, more stable charging base with places to store brush heads<br />3. Cheap replacement brushes (providing you didn't fall for the &#34;free brush&#34; scam where they sent you a new brush each month and charged 6 bucks for shipping) and flosser snap-ins. Of course this cost depends on how often you replaced brushes and flossers.<br /><br />Other comments:<br />1. Cybersonic batteries kept charging fully for many years, I will let you know eventually how long the Sonicare batteries last.<br />2. I can see right away that the small, light charging base will fall over easily and possibly drop the unit off the countertop. I'm thinking once I am sure where I want to keep the charging base, I'll put a dab of silicone caulk under it to hold it steady.<br />3. Don't get me wrong, I do like the Sonicare, it's speedy and really feels like it is getting my teeth cleaner, but I will still keep the remaining handle and floss heads of the Cybersonic until they die completely and then look for more on eBay. That flosser is a thousand times better than flossing string or tape, works very well and very fast.better than flossing string or tape, works very well and very fast.

  513. All I know is I am very pleased with this unit! My teeth have never felt cleaner and since I am mostly disabled by a stroke this works really well for me.
  514. It has four beeps to let you know when to move on to the next area. I like that. It also initially works up to full speed the first dozen times or so. This helps your mouth get used to the vibration. It gets my teeth really clean, I love it.
  515. I was skeptical about buying this because I was doing a good job with my manual toothbrush. This electric does a better job of doing my back molars and it reaches deeper in between the teeth. My teeth feel noticeably cleaner with this as opposed to a manual brush. Battery lasts for many brushes on a single charge.<br /><br />I bought this specific model because the higher priced models from Sonicare are a waste of money. The higher end models are the same hardware, but with a different outer skin and more software programming. The extra software options are not useful: they just vary the length of time and lower the intensity of the brushing action. Most people will not use these extra \\"features.\\" If you need more time, you can turn the brush on again. Lowering the intensity defeats the purpose of an electric brush. A lower intensity is only useful if your teeth are very sensitive due to poor hygiene or due to injury.<br /><br />The lower end models use the older style brush heads. I don't know for how long Sonicare will continue to provide replaceable heads for those, so I went with the cheapest model that uses the newest heads.<br /><br />Sonicare's highest end model (DiamondClean) claims to clean even better than this model. That is only true of the brush head that model comes with. Those particular DiamondClean brush heads are compatible with this EasyClean model and can be purchased separately; therefore, cleaning performance between the two models are exactly the same.<br /><br />Bottom line: This EasyClean model is the only model I recommend. Anything more expensive does not really provide anything extra (despite what the marketing department wants you to believe), and anything less expensive uses the old brush heads.
  516. Great item. Well worth the price. Takes a bit getting used to when it comes to the speed it goes. I am used to my $25 Oral B Vitality electric toothbrush I have been using for years. Night and day difference between this and cheaper models. I believe it is well worth the extra price to get the &#34;Quadpacer&#34; setting that goes in 30 second intervals and stops for a second and continues telling you to change pattern and direction. With my old toothbrush I used just to clean all over for two minutes in general. This breaks your mouth down into 4 quad sections for better cleaning.<br /><br />Well worth it for sure!

  522. Iâ€™ve been using Sonicare toothbrushes for many years and am a major fan. It also has Quadpacer which I consider essential. As a side benefit, the brush heads are cheaper, it uses lithium batteries (which are lighter and last longer) and the charger is smaller. Iâ€™ve been using it for a few weeks and consider it a major improvement over the Essence series. Anyone considering purchasing an Essence should also note that the current Essence model does not have Quadpacer. Do yourself a favor and spend the few extra bucks for the Easyclean. It is the cheapest model that has all the important features. Check out my review of the Essence for a comparison.

  533. I had the original Sonicare for several years and loved what it did for my teeth. What I didn't like was apparently the same things everyone else didn't like: the size, the so-so battery life and the filth that would form inside the handle and brush heads. All of those problem have been eliminated. This model is slim and feels good in the hand; the older model felt like a vintage hot rod, great at what it was supposed to do but lacking the tightness that comes with modern engineering. Cleaning was a tremendous hassle on the older model and part I least liked about it. I've had this model for a month and it still looks as clean as it did the day it arrived. Finally, the battery life has been exceptional. My wife and I both use this twice a day and we are still on the initial charge; the old one needed a charge every 5-6 days.<br /><br />This is definitely one of the best consumer products I've purchased in a while.
  534. There are many excellent reviews for this toothbrush on here, hundreds in fact, so I just want to highlight some of my main observations:<br />- this model is very good value, and I do not see benefits of getting the higher end ones (I used to have a top end Braun and never used its extra modes or features);<br />- the depth of cleaning outperforms the Braun (both in feeling and in reports back from my dentist)<br />- the battery life is excellent, lasting at least two weeks on 2-3 minutes of brushing twice a day (my Braun was 3-5 days when new and down to 2 days after a couple of days)<br />- the sensation of brushing takes a few weeks to get used to (it gradually rises in intensity over a couple of weeks, but still felt pretty intense) but once you are used to it, it feels absolutely fine<br />- the old style heads and those of the Braun catch all kinds of crud and gunk but these new Sonicare heads stay clean and sanitary all the time<br />- yes, replacement heads are expensive compared to a normal toothbrush, so this is a more expensive option, but the results for your dental health are worth it

  573. I have used this more than 1 year and now I decided to give it a review because it suddenly stopped work.<br />It will start automatically by itself, and I cannot even stop it by press the button.<br />So I contacted the amazon service asking about the warranty information. But the agent have no idea about the warranty information and ask me to call Philips. Of course he/she gave the number to call.<br />I think Amazon should improve in this area, they should always know the warranty information about the product on their site, not direct customers to the manufacturers.<br /><br />Ok. anyway, I called Philips. I told the agent the serial number and he directly asked me an address to replace it with a new one! that really surprised me a lot. (Usually I need to spend an hour to get a replacement for warranty, because they always have some kind of excuse)<br />But worth mentioning, I stay in Singapore, Philips only offer shipping to US or Canada. So he advised me that they can ship it to my friend in US, and my friend can help ship it to me.<br />That is just too much trouble, so I asked is there anything I can do to fix it by myself.<br />He told me I can try to reset it.<br />Basically, fully charge, hold the button for 10 second. release it, turn off.<br />Bang! It works now!<br />It is really good service from Philips, I have been a customer of them many years for many products.<br />Despite their recent discontinuing RQ12 shaver head, they are still doing a good job.<br /><br />Besides all these, I think the product itself is pretty good.   582. Bought it locally. Using the original ProResults and black DiamondClean heads together (looks really sweet with those by the way). Love it so much that I can't wait to finish this review and go brush my teeth. 2014/11/8 Edit: Since I wrote this lazy \\"review\\" I got the Flexcare & Healthy White Plastic Travel Handle Case. It fits perfectly. The DiamondClean heads too even though their bases are a bit wider. Do get it, you won't regret it. Almost two months of usage, the brush has yet to disappoint me. It's my little morning joy. It certainly works! Never had such smooth teeth, let alone the back ones. It's just a matter of getting used to the brush and you start feeling every hair's location despite the vibration. During the first week I literally abused it - brushed 3-4 times a day and it still managed way past 2 weeks on one charge. Function wise - no need for more buttons, more accessories (except for the case), more lights, more programs etc. If I need to brush some more, I turn it on again. If the battery is low, it vibrates when switching off, and can work for some days more. That's it. 30+ years of manual brushing forgotten in less than a week. Good riddance!
  583. I have used Sonicare toothbrushes for years. My old brush finally gave out so had to get a new one. I like the new brush heads as they do not get dirty and the handle is slimmer. Can't go wrong with this brush.

  585. This is the third Sonicare brush I've owned in the last 15 years and I credit them with maintaining my oral health to the point where I hardly ever need any work at the dentist!<br /><br />This latest version has slimmed down the handle significantly, which is not a bad thing. However the stand has also been minimized and that's not so good. Firstly the inherent 'torque' in the power cord makes it hard to set it securely on the counter top, it keeps trying to twist away, particularly when the brush is in use. Second the little spigot that the brush rests on, combined with the base's very small footprint, doesn't really hold it securely and I've already knocked or dropped the brush on the floor as a result.<br /><br />Excellent product apart from this.

I had an Oral B one before, and never got such comments from the dentist (but it was a different dentist--maybe they had different standards??). The good check-up probably has something to do with genes, but I really believe this toothbrush helped.<br />By the way, I looked at a lot of the different Sonicare models before purchasing. I think it is worth getting the Easy Clean because it has the beeps to mark 30 seconds. This is very valuable, I found previously, with just a 2-minute shut off, I would often turn the brush off before the 2 mins was up. Now, I have no problem making it to 2 mins and sometimes even go over. In my opinion, Sonicare models that are more expensive than this one do not offer features that make them worth the price.
  593. I've been using a Philips Sonicare toothbrush for about six years. A few months ago, my previous one died. It was the Flexcare model, which has four cleaning modes (sensitive, massage, \\"on-the-go\\" and cleaning). My husband uses a manual toothbrush, so I went out and got myself one. I'd forgotten how useless they are for cleaning this tea drinker's teeth. My teeth got noticeably more stained. So, being a bit of a cheapskate, I bought a battery powered toothbrush. Awful! It made a terrible racket, made my gums sore, and didn't do any better of a job cleaning my teeth than the manual one.<br /><br />I missed my Sonicare.<br /><br />I bought my previous model at my dentist's office, but wondered if there were any new models that my dentist didn't carry so I got onto Amazon. Lo and behold, there was this model, which there was a coupon for, thus making it about fifty dollars less than the model I figured I'd buy again. I never once used any of the special cleaning modes when I had the Flexcare model, so this one made sense to me.<br /><br />I actually like this one better. The charger stand is a bit smaller and looks nicer sitting on my sink. It does the same job. You can use any of the Sonicare heads, including the Diamond head that comes with their top of the line model. That is the one I use and it does a great job of keeping my teeth looking good and feeling almost as clean as if I had just gone to the dental hygienist.<br /><br />If you drink coffee or black tea (especially tea) you simply must use a Sonicare! I sound like a shill for the company, but I don't think they need any help. I'm just a happy customer.

The brushes hardly moved compared to my older Essence. So I returned the Easy clean to Amazon. Then I figured that maybe I got a bad unit. I went to Walmart and purchased a new Easy Clean and a new Essence. I charged and set both to full power (not easy start of ramp-up). I would say that the Essence has twice the brushing power of the newer style Sonicare. I want a brush that really challenges my gums; and that is exactly what Sonicare recommends. They say use the highest settings always. Well the Easy clean is like a massaging brush rather than full power clean. I am keeping the new Essence and returning the Easy Clean. I would bet that all new models have the same problem because of the slender body that keeps side to side vibration in check. The Essence is a trade off in that the user must remove the head after use and wash in under water. It is not a sealed unit. But it's a small price to pay for better performance. Beware that more expensive is NOT better.

  669. First, mine came with a travel case and two toothbrushes. Ive used the Braun electric toothbrush with quite satisfactory results since 1990. To a large extent, the work is being done by the brush heads, therefore one can get different results depending on which you use. To a large extent, I find the wide array of brushes unnecessary. Now to the Sonicare. The first thing I did was to deactivate the 14 day ramp up system. This is good for first time electric toothbrush users. You generally get a little bleeding when you start with an electric toothbrush. Next I noticed how small the brush heads are. Now on to my perceptions. The head actually moves very little compared to the Braun Oral-B system. But this does not equate to less effective cleaning. This seems to clean much quicker to to the much more rapid vibration than the Oral-B. At the end of the 2 minute timer, my teeth were clean. An impressive feat. So, I recommend this without hesitation.

  696. If you are currently using the Sonicare E series brush, the Sonicare HX6511/50 Easy Clean is definitely worth the upgrade! It's much easier to switch out the brush heads on this if you're sharing the handle, and the charger is smaller than the E series charger also. You might think that 60 bucks is a lot to spend on a toothbrush, but the condition of your teeth can have a major effect on your overall health. Seeing the dentist because you've neglected your teeth has an adverse effect on your wallet too! An ounce of prevention . . . blah blah yada yada. :-D
  697. This thing is incredible! When people say 'it feels like you just left the dentist' that is no joke. The very nice smooth feeling is replicated with this toothbrush.
