It is very simple to use, although if you read the manual (which I highly recommend, it's a quick read) it will show you the few things you need to do to keep the brush working well and how the timing mechanism works. Very good product!
  698. This is my third Sonicare and will buy more in the future. The batteries don't last forever (second one lasted 7 years) but having the dental hygienist hardly touch me is well worth it. The Braun's brush head has lots of places for stuff to grow, so keep those heads in some mouthwash.
  699. I bought a basic Sonicare a few years ago. It did a wonderful job of cleaning my teeth but after a while the area where the brush head attached to the handle became all gunked up and the brush didn't work. It wasn't easy to take it apart and clean it regularly, so I had to throw out an expensive piece of equipment and I bought a cheaper, easy-to-maintain brush instead.<br /><br />Well, my teeth weren't happy, nor was my dentist. But in the real world, people don't have time or often, the manual dexterity, to dissassemble a toothbrush and clean it with Q-tips (!) frequently (or ever). Recently, my dentist showed me that Philips had redesigned the brush so that the brushhead fits onto a spike (exactly like the cheaper brush I had been using). So I bought this new model, and the difference is obvious from the first use.<br /><br />You're not going to get a better brush in terms of cleaning. Now you won't have to throw out this relatively expensive brush after a few months. \\"Cleaning\\" it now means simply removing the brushhead--just pull it off--and running the place where it attaches to the base under water. If you register your purchase, it's warranteed for two years, so it's an excellent investment.<br /><br />My only recommendation to Philips is that the handle is still too smooth for a firm grip, especially when you're dealing with the icky realities of toothpaste, water and saliva. A more textured surface would be better. But five stars for making an essential improvement--and it was always a great brush.
  700. I purchased this toothbrush as a replacement to my HX6950 because the metal tip where the brush head connects became loose and fell off after being dropped. I never used any of the other options that the HX6950 offers such as Gum Care, Refresh, etc., so the one function on the HX6511/50 is good enough for me. This toothbrush uses the same type of brush heads, ProResults, which is good since I have replacement heads at the ready. One thing that I was not aware of when I first used this model was that it has an \\"Easy-start\\" feature which increases power over the first 14 uses to ease you into the Sonicare experience. Having already been used to the full power of the HX6950, I felt like the HX6511/50 was extremely weak at first, but I am noticing that it is increasingly getting stronger, so that is good. The only complaint I really have about it now is that it doesn't display how much charge it has, it only flashes a light when battery is getting low.<br /><br />One thing I do recommend is that you remove the brush head and rinse the connecting parts after each use. If you keep the brush head on, over time old toothpaste begins to build up and I noticed on my old HX6950 that mold had started to grow on the rubber that is attached to the metal tip. It was easily cleaned off with bleach and did not return as long as I let the area air out after each use. The Hx6511/50 has a slightly different design in this area which uses less of the rubber protector, so hopefully it won't be an issue, but I would still remove the brush head after cleaning anyway.<br /><br />Overall, if you are just looking for an electric toothbrush without the need for extra features such as Sensitive, Refresh, or Massage, this toothbrush works great. I have not used any other electric toothbrushes, but I have used a regular toothbrush when I was out of town and forgot my Sonicare, and I did not feel clean at all after brushing. The Sonicare really delivers a good cleaning and you can tellright away the difference between a standard toothbrush and the Philips Sonicare. I would continue to purchase the Sonicare products in the future if/when this toothbrush goes out on me.
  701. Used for two years and would never go back to manual brushing. Really cleans and gets plaque between teeth. Love the super clean feeling the ultrasonic waves give you. If your using grocery store electric toothbrush it's not ultrasonic and not cleaning as well as this brush does. Only ultrasonic waves can break up the cell membrane wall of bacteria, melting the bacteria not just brushing them around. Replacement heads are not cheep for soniccare but totally worth it.

  739. I have only had this for a day but like it so much I felt a review was a good idea. I used to have a Sonicare a few years back but had the problem of gunk getting stuck in the middle chamber (where the brush attaches) and I'd have to clean my toothbrush with every use. I see from reviews that several other people had the same problem. CLeaning my toothbrush each time does not seem like something I should have to bother with and, after a while, I got rid of it and went back to the simple brush. After a trip to a new dentist, whom I trust, she definitely recommended an electric brush as it cleans so much better. I decided to pick up a battery-powered Oral B from the drugstore so I can check out that brand and have some time to decide on what to buy. At first I liked the circular brush, but the thing felt heavy and clunky and somewhat sloppy compared to the Sonicare (yes, I know there is a difference between the battery powdered models and the more expensive offerings). I am glad to have found this newer model here on Amazon. The new brush design seems to work fine - no icky gunk - and the power of the brush seems more intense than I remember (my hand really felt the vibration), but I get a thorough cleaning. My teeth felt just as good as when I leave the dentist's office. Also, the charging base is simple (and it charged quickly) and I personally like that there aren't extra decorations and details in different colors attached to this thing. I just want a toothbrush...and I got it. Would definitely recommend.
  740. Like others who posted reviews, this Sonicare is an upgrade from the circular Oral-B, which I had for years. Worked fine--why get another one? Well, I wish I hadn't waited this long. I've had it a week and it's like a dental revelation. With the Oral-B, I confess that there was still plaque on my teeth after brushing (take my word for it). I also confess that I am a bad brusher. In fact, I purchased the Oral-B after being berated by my hygienist for not flossing. \\"But I floss every day,\\" I said. \\"Hmph,\\" she said. \\"Then you are an executive brusher,\\" i.e., I sped through my brushings doing only the summary work. The Oral-B and its timer helped, but it was so hard to tell how long you were supposed to spend in each area, that I probably still sped through (though more effectively than the manual brushing). The Sonicare and its quad-pacing, though, has put an end to my speedy brushing ways. My teeth are also definitely cleaner because the brush seems to do a better job of getting into nooks and crannies. It's gentler than my previous brush, too. The one negative--and this could be a deal-breaker for some--is the buzzines, which may remind some people (like my husband) of being at the dentist's office. If you bump your teeth, everything goes \\"BZZZZZ\\" and that may freak some people out. Me, not an issue. I'm happy and the test will be the next visit to the dentist when I expect to have a less painful time in the chair.
  741. Bought this as XMAS gift so I've owned this for a short while. I've used it a couple of times and like a lot of reviews that I read I have to just get used to it. Also, I will update this review if good or bad things occur (hopefully all good). I must say that in the short time I've used it, i really like the timer on this unit but I've come to realize that I used to brush for a lot longer using my regular, manual, non electric oral b toothbrush (two minutes seems to short for me). I like the feature that allows you to ease into using an electric toothbrush according to the instructions, this feature must be disabled after about two weeks of use--it's a gentler brushing mode (which is probably why I noticed the very first time that I used it that my teeth didn't feel all that clean). One oddity: I've noticed more sensitivity in my teeth after just two brushing (not sure if this has anything to do with holiday eating/drinking or the new toothbrush as that brush moves very fast). I've added sensitive paste to my regimen. What I didn't like was that I had a dickens of a time finding the brush replacements (it was confusing as to which model goes with what). Also, without seeing this product, i was unsure about the size head (compact or full) to get. Since my purchase, I found the replacement heads at my grocery store of all places (price is not necessarily better). This toothbrush is quiet, from my POV (a lot of reviews mentioned noise but I found it to be very quiet). It's weird when the plastic brush head hits a tooth and my whole head vibrates, again, in my opinion, it's a matter of getting used to this method of brushing. Again, I would give this 5 stars but I'm a very new user. Overall pleased with this purchase from Amazon.

  749. good<br /><br />a da a a a af s asf fg g ggwg g af af fgsdf afdfg dfa af sa
  750. About a year ago my parents sent me an electric toothbrush (<$20) because they were impressed with new ones that had recently tried. I was favorably impressed with the cleaning, but found that replacing the batteries always resulted in the waterproof seal being damaged and the batteries would flood. I went through about 4 of them, with at least a couple different types, and the story was always the same. Occasionally the heads would work their way apart too, even though they were within their regular use period.<br /><br />You have 2 types to choose from if you step up in quality: Oral-B (with the round spinning heads) and Philips (with the more traditional up and down stroke head). My personal preference is the Philips type of head. After much research, I found that the older Philips models, with the much bigger base to the replaceable brush end, were getting reports of significant material (toothpaste, saliva, etc.) remaining under the bigger base. For this reason I chose the least expensive of the smaller head toothbrushes, the Easy Clean, which had reviews as high as their most expensive models.<br /><br />Cleaning under the head is very easy, as I imagine it would be under the larger heads, but there is simply very little there to clean. The brush heads do a great job, and i have no doubt my teeth have never been cleaner. The design allows me to reach anywhere in my mouth, and after a little getting used to it, I am fine with the 'quadrant' system it uses. This way, you brush upper or bottom, left or right teeth for 30 seconds, then the toothbrush gives a slight beep, encouraging you to move to the next quadrant. In 2 minutes, you are done and it shuts off. This forces you to focus on exactly where you are brushing, to make sure you don't 'run out of time'. I used to brush longer, but now with the stroke speed and the strict timing, my teeth are much cleaner in a guaranteed 2 minutes. Of course you could turn the brush on again, but if you pay attention, thereis no need to to do this.<br /><br />Since stroke speed is very fast, there apparently is an initial 14 day break in period, whereby the brush moves slower to start, but increases in speed over each of those uses. This can be reset if ever needed. I didn't really notice this change over time, but I guess that is part of the intent.<br /><br />The charging base is miniscule, with a simple structure, but very effective and requires virtually no effort to insert the toothbrush.<br /><br />The toothbrush itself is not cheap, but is well priced through Amazon. The individual heads are quite pricey $8-$10 each, but can be bought in packs of 2-4 to save a little bit. If this cost were to drop somewhat, I'm sure the number of users would increase dramatically.<br /><br />Great product that exceeded my expectations! I wish I had bought one years earlier, and probably would have if the cost wasn't such an issue.
  751. My daughters have been using this for quite a while and bugging me to get one. When my dentist suggested it was a good idea, I bought it. I love it. It becomes a good habit fast. My teeth and gums feels not only clean but massaged. Wonderful. Don't wait.
  752. I have used an old style Sonicare brush for about 10 years with great results. It worked fine although the battery was starting to fade as it would not hold a charge beyond a week which was a problem on trips. The real reason I wanted to upgrade was the design of the old brush. I was becoming concerned about and tired cleaning the gunk that was getting in between the brush head and the handle. The new brush design clearly fixed this issue. The other Sonicare models had modes and features I did not want or need. If you want Bright White just brush twice.<br /><br />I registered my brush and was given a 25% one time coupon code that could only be used on Sonicare.com.. I bought another brush for my wife as well as a year supply of brushes that was cheaper than buying on Amazon.<br /><br />If you are on the fence about the price of the brush you will not be sorry. I can't imagine ever going back to a manual brush!

  754. i love this toothbrush

  756. My teeth have never felt cleaner!

  758. I have been using Sonicare brushes for several years. I applied for a rebate after I bought this particular product in April. I was told to expect a rebate within 8 to 10 weeks. After 12 weeks I contacted them and was told my application had not been processed yet. Yesterday I got a postcard from Philips saying they could not honor my request since I had not submitted the UPC bar code. I decided it was time to throw my copy of the rebate from in the recycling bin and toss the cardboard box (minus the UPC bar code I had cut out and submitted) into the cardboard recycling box. This is the second and last time they have done this to me. I think Sonicare is a great product. But I will never buy another one. The one star is for their lack of honesty with their consumers.
  759. This toothbrush takes some getting used to--the action of the sonic bristles tickles the gums but they do a far better job cleaning teeth than other brushes (battery powered or muscle powered) I have used.
  760. This is the first time I got a Sonicare toothbrush and I am not disappointed! It gives me the best clean feel after I am finished and I absolutely love the timer function so I know I clean each quadrant of my mouth equally and for a full 2 minutes. It feels like you just left the dentist after every brushing and I definitely notice that my teeth are whiter and gums are healthier.
  761. Bought this to replace my 2-years old Flexcare with ultrasonic cleaning module. For the last year, the flexcare was producing a loud sound, probably due to the interface between the brush and the handle. When not turned on, the brush can be moved easily; I believe it is loose or partially broken. The flexcare has too many useless options (for me, but maybe not for others). All I needed was a two minute timer with 30 seconds interval indicator. The HX6511 was half the price and lighter. It's simple. The gap between the brush and the handle was half of the flexcare; it's a much tighter fit and more secured. It feels solid and no extraneous sound; hopefully this will last a long time. Overall, it's painless to use and have been using the sonicare toothbrush since the beginning of the product inception. Love it!
  762. I have been using a battery-powered Sonicare. My wife wanted one of her own but preferred a rechargeable unit. This one fit the bill. I have owned a Sonicare rechargeable in the past that was much more expensive, and this certainly performs as well at much lower cost.
  763. I purchased this in December 2013 so have been using it for a little over a year. This replaced an earlier model which was still working well. But the old style brush heads got filthy inside even with daily cleaning. The Easy Clean is a big improvement. It is reliable and it is easy to take the brush off the unit for cleaning. (It still needs to be cleaned often as it is not completely sealed.) I use it twice or three times a day and charge it once a week, but it could go longer before requiring a charge. I am totally fine with everything about it. I recently received an upscale version of the Phillips Sonicare so had an opportunity to compare with the Easy Clean. The upscale version has several modes and is a bit of a more elegant design, but costs more than twice as much. I definitely would not purchase anything higher than the Easy Clean, which does just as effective a job.
  764. Great value. I used to use Sonicare several years ago then went back to using a regular brush. I've just started using it again and notice a big difference. My teeth feel a lot cleaner. I researched many of the available models and the Easy Clean seemed like the best option. I didn't need all of the useless bells and whistles. I'm glad that it's dual voltage 110/240 so that I can use it while I travel and that the charging stand is extremely small and portable. I briefly though about getting the Diamond Clean with the USB charger, which would have been nice, but the case is so huge and I like to travel light. The only downside to the charging stand is that it can be wobbly and take a bit of effort to get it in position without making the brush fall over. I just wish they'd stick a micro USB input in the bottom and call it good, it would probably charge faster too. Battery life is excellent and it's easy to clean. By they way it fits the Diamond Clean heads as well so there's really no reason to spend more money on a fancier model with all of the different modes that you'll never use. I'm a happy customer.
  765. Great toothbrush. I have had sonicare brushes for the last 6 years. I bought this one to replace the last one because the battery died after several years of use. This one is even better because it doesn't let gunk build up at the base of the brush like older models, and the charger is compatible for 110-220 V (unlike the last one). I had to rely on a single charge when I went traveling before, but I don't have that issue any more. You can also get the diamond brushes to replace the brushhead.

  773. I've just received this Sonicare toothbrush so I really don't have a strong opinion yet. However, I do have three questions: A - It comes with two heads and the only description of them appears on the box and are very similar, i.e. gentle, gum lines, etc. One head has all green bristles, the other head has a mixture of blue and green. So, has anyone found a significant difference? B - Admittedly, I've just used it for 2 days but when the bristles come in contact with my gums, lips, etc. the vibration causes a &#34;ticklish&#34; sensation where the bristles touch my skin. Perhaps that comes with the territory when you are using a brush with 31,000 strokes per minute. My question is: does that ticklish feeling decrease or disappear over time as my skin becomes acclimated to the vibration? C - Regarding the various beeps and timers: Is there any way to defeat this silly feature? I don't need an annoying noise to tell me to move to another section of my teeth. So, is there any way to use the on/off switch to, well, just turn it on and off and avoid the distraction of having to listen to beeps and/or having the brush stop altogether? Thanks.

  813. I had a more expensive Oral B cleaner that I tossed because of this guy here. The Oral B was much louder and even the soft bristles were rigid and rough on the gums. The medium bristle that I got with this is an order of magnitude softer than the sensitive Oral B that I have and I've yet to open the package of soft bristles for the Sonicare.<br /><br />What I love about this toothbrush aside from it not being as rough on the gums is that it is clean! No matter how hard I rinsed out the Oral B one, I would end up with a bunch of disgusting gunk on the charging base. It looked really nasty. This happened even after I removed the head after every brush and got water in all the hollow places where the nasty saliva toothpaste mixture could hide. Not to mention if you didn't do a good job rinsing it out, you could sometimes taste the old nasty toothpaste gunk that hid out in the hollow portion of the toothbrush head.<br /><br />I've had this brush for over a month now and I've yet to clean the base. No crud, awesome! That stuff annoyed me to no end. That alone is worth the price of entry, no joke. It does a good job cleaning the grill too and it ramps up gradually so you don't get freaked out by the way it feels because it is a strange feeling.<br /><br />One thing I don't like about it is that due to the (wild guess here) way sonic vibrations work, it seems to collapse all the bubbles and foam that you normally get with brushing. I personally think the timer is set a little too short for my liking, as I go two full cycles but I end up with a mouth full of liquid toothpaste, water, saliva mixture with zero bubbles. You basically spit it out of your mouth like a stream of water. This is a little strange if you're used to a bunch of foam from the tooth paste.<br /><br />That and good heavens, tooth brush heads are expensive as hell. I imagine the markup on the heads is a couple thousand percent as all the tech is in the body and Sonicare tech isn't exactly new so R&D costshave been recouped a long time ago. You can't exactly come up with new, &#34;innovative&#34; ways to come up with vibrations.

  839. UPDATE<br />November 28, 2013<br />After 1 year and 7 months, the toothbrush started to act strangely. It would spontaneously turn on and not brush for the full two minutes. I was often woken up at night because it would turn on and vibrate its way into the sink and just make a racket. I called up Philips and they replaced the unit. Philips also covered the shipping. I was fortunate because the unit has a 2 year warranty but when I registered, they gave me an extra 6 months. I was still well within my warranty period. I am very impressed with Philips and their customer service. Also, my dentist says my teeth are spectacular and visits are now nearly pain free. I highly recommend this product because, if it fails, Philips will replace it and it produces good teeth cleaning results.<br /><br />March 19, 2012<br />After a lot of research and speaking to my dentist (who recommended either this brush or an Oral-B circular rotating brush, the latter of which she favoured), I chose the Sonicare.<br />I chose it because, for me, the sonicating action is better at removing plaque and food debris from my teeth. It is also very gentle on my gums (I have previously had a problem of receding gums that has since halted now that I've switched from a manual brush).<br />I fully charge this brush and take it travelling. So far I've used it for 3 days without charging, brushing three times/day (9 sessions in total) and the battery lasted.<br />I recommend this because of the excellent cleaning power, gentleness on my gums and the long battery life.

  853. My last Sonicare lasted for over 7 years. It cleaned my teeth fantastically twice a day that whole time. When the battery finally stopped holding a charge, I did not even consider another brand. This new one has an even better design, in that the top just snaps on, so it is easier to keep clean. There are models with more features, but when you read through the marketing hype, it's just longer brushing time, or variable power levels. This one cleans perfectly with its single power level, and I can just use it twice if I want extra brushing time. Well worth the money.

  873. My wife and I have both been happy Sonicare users for many years. When she found these locally on sale and with a rebate, we could not say \\"no\\". Each of us has an older model with a big screw-on brush head assembly. Not only are replacement heads more expensive for that type but they also provide lots of space for crud to build up that requires regular cleaning or it gets really nasty.<br /><br />The Easy Clean looks like it should be much simpler to keep in a hygienic condition. My wife is happy with the reduced size and weight compared to our older brushes. For the price, you really can not do better although the more expensive Sonicare's do come with additional features (that may not matter to you) and sometimes accessories. The one thing missing with this brush is a travel case. Luckily, a quick search on Amazon found one with high ratings.<br /><br />Probably the most important part of a toothbrush is how well it cleans teeth. My experience is with regular brushes and with 3 different Sonicare models. With a regular brush, my teeth do not feel nearly as clean no matter how long I brush. With the Sonicare, 2 minutes (via the built-in timer) gives really clean feeling teeth in a way that I can not at this time imagine purchasing any other brand of toothbrush. Both my wife and I are extremely happy with our new brushes!

  875. Love this product. Love the design, love how it performs, and the technical savvy internals. It comes with several pre-programmed settings right out of the box. I like how one of them, it gradually increases the power of the toothbrush over x amount of days. My particular favorite, and the one that I continue to use, is the timer feature. Every 30 seconds, you brush a region of your mouth. It'll send a pulse to let you know when that time is up. What's neat, least I think it's neat -- is that if you push the power button once, and then again in less than I believe 30 seconds, you can continue to go back to that timer feature.<br />All in all a great brush that is affordable, as well as super easy to clean. Also, the battery seems to never die. Honestly I've been 3 weeks in between charges and that's only because I wanted to charge it.

  908. First off, I have been using Sonicare toothbrushes for many years and am very happy (as is my dental hygienist) with the cleaning results. This toothbrush replaced an older Sonicare that finally died after years of use. I chose this unit because it was the least cost that still included the 30 second interval timer (beep tone), a feature that I liked with the old brush. The new unit is much smaller and lighter overall than the old unit making it more convenient to maneuver around your teeth. The charging stand is smaller too, taking up less space. The really nice design feature is the easy push-on / pull-off brush head as opposed to the threaded collar connector on the old style. Not all Sonicare models have the push-on connection feature, so if you want this you should buy the EasyClean, FlexCare, or Diamond models. I don't know how it could be better except if the replacement brushes were less costly. You do well to get them for $9-10 each.

  934. I bought this Sonicare to replace a more expensive model I had that broke. The more expensive model used a rubber sleeve at the base of the metal post that holds the brush. The sleeve is designed to keep water out of the insides of the unit. This model (which is like $40 cheaper - I don't remember exactly) uses a hard plastic sleeve instead of rubber and I've found it to be a much better design. I've been using Sonicare brushes since Phillips started making them and have had several different models. I think this one is the best yet. It has the quadrabeep feature to tell you how long to brush each quadrant of your teeth but lacks some of the more advanced settings found on the more expensive models. I don't miss those extra features at all and will likely go with this model (or similar) when I eventually need to replace this one - I don't think that will be any time soon unless I break it myself though. The design improvement I mentioned above is part of an overall improvement in quality over older models. This brush is well-built and in my opinion the best Sonicare I've ever owned.

  954. I received this as a gift and thought that it was just another toothbrush albeit higher end. I could not be more wrong. I had issues brushing with it the first two days as it tickled my gums but then I got used to it. I could immediately see that my teeth were several shades whiter and I even received compliments from family members who noticed the difference. In addition, the areas between my teeth were also cleaner before flossing. Now I am gifting these toothbrushes to all my family members. UPDATE: I am updating these reviews to reflect my discontent with the instructions and warn other users. The brush is made well and does whiten your teeth; HOWEVER, the instructions tell you to only brush the front and back of your teeth. I assumed this was due to some technology in or the size of the brush making it clean the tops/bottoms of your teeth as well. Nope -- despite using this, flossing, and rinsing twice a day, I had two cavities on the tops of my back teeth. If you follow the instructions and do not brush the tops/bottoms of your teeth, you will develop cavities... so keeping in mind this flaw in the instructions and making sure to brush your entire mouth, this could be a five-star product.
  955. My old one gave out after years of use. If you have teeth and want to keep them, this thing is for you.
  956. Second one in 4 years. Works great. My teeth look and feel clean. Just hope this one lasts longer then the first one.

  968. This toothbrush is exactly what I was hoping for. No gimicky features, just a straightforward electric model. The vibration took a few days to get accustomed to but over all much more pleasant than the OralB spin brushes I have used in the past. After a few months of use my teeth are noticeably whiter and my gums have never been healthier.
  969. Replaced an earlier model with this one because I hated the grunge that would get into the handle. This is a nicer and cleaner design.
  970. People should know that this Sonicare brush comes with the &#34;Easy-start&#34; feature activated. That means the brush increases power gradually over the first 14 uses. I think that's why some reviews say it's not as powerful as their other brushes. To turn Easy-start off; attach the brush head on the handle and put the handle on the charger. Then hold the button on the brush for 2 seconds and you should hear a beep. Now, it should run at full power. To turn it back on, do the same and you will hear 2 beeps.
  971. Best toothbrush ever. Easy to clean, and gets the job done! Also quieter than the other Sonicare models, as far as I can tell.
  972. Nice toothbrush, but very pricey, and the starter head bristles are a little too hard and sharp for my liking. Easy to clean.
  973. I started using Sonicare toothbrushes several years ago when I was sick of getting my teeth scraped at the dentist. Ever since I started using the Sonicare, I no longer have to worry about painful scraping. This particular sonicare is smart enough to tell me when to switch areas of brushing in my mouth - it's dummy proof.<br /><br />This purchase was for my teenage daughter with braces. Sonicare has kept her teeth white and cavity free through all of the orthodontic work she was been through.
  974. Awesome product, motor is very powerful and leaves my teeth feeling like I just left from the dentist.<br />The charger is a 110-220 so you dont need to worry if your in europe.<br /><br />Cons:<br />The timer is nice but I spend more than 30 seconds on each section and it auto shuts off after 2 mins.   977. This does an amazing job! At my recent dental hygiene appointment, the hygienist said that my teeth were really clean and she noticed the difference from my last cleaning. Would not go back to the manual toothbrush ever!
  978. I absolutely love this toothbrush. I love the simplicity of the one button on and off, without having to cycle through various modes to turn the thing off, I like the automatic shut off after 2 minutes. I had the earlier Sonicare models with the screw on brush heads, and the new snap on style is much cleaner, the brush itself is slimmer, lighter, and I find more ergonomically friendly. The lithium ion battery in this thing beats the pants off of the battery life of the Oral B 3000 I also own, it goes about twice as long without having to be recharged. The one thing I have changed from the previous Sonicare's I have owned, is that the previous two I kept on the charger all the time, but the last one died within about a year, and would no longer hold a charge. With this one (and the Oral B) I let the battery run down before I recharge even though the manual says overcharging isn't possible, I really would prefer not to have to replace them in a year. I actually bought the SoniCare not long after I purchased the Oral B, because I really missed the way the Sonicare felt and cleaned my gums but I didn't dislike the Oral B, so I just kept both and I like them both in their own different ways, so I rotate using them. But I do much prefer this brush, this I think is the best electric toothbrush on the market. The higher end/more expensive models have features that I just wouldn't use, but this one is worth it for the Lion battery.
  979. So far so good. I've had it for a month or two and really like it. Purchased it when my old Sonicare croaked. If you haven't had one before, you will love how clean it leaves your teeth feeling. The reason I purchased this model was that the last one I had would get nasty/funky where the brushhead attached and it really creeped me out. Would clean it and it'd be back in no time. This one is designed in such a way that there isn't a place for water/toothpaste to get into. As long is lasts, I'll be a happy camper. It holds a charge for a long time, too.
  980. After using this toothbrush for 2 months I can safely say I love it much more than the previous model (ESeries).   982. I was a Braun user for many years. I was very happy with the Braun, but after my last Braun wore out (it stopped working after a couple of years), my wife suggested we try the Sonicare. I was a little worried because I was happy with what we had been using, but I took a chance bought the Easy Clean. Boy am I glad I did. It is a lot different than the Braun. There's no question it removes more plaque the Braun and my teeth are much cleaner. The power of the sonic action obliterates any gunk between your teeth especially calcium buildup. I would get calcium buildup around my teeth even with brushing three times a day. The Sonicare Easy Clean got rid of all of it within a few days and my gums are much healthier. It's a clean you can see and feel.<br /><br />I like the head it came with, but I recently bought a six pack of the InterCare brush heads. Bad move, the Intercare costs more, but I like the original head better. The InterCare are a little smaller and seem a little softer. I'll buy the &#34;Pro Results&#34; next time.<br /><br />This was the best purchase I've made in a long time. Definitely buy the newer models like the Easy Clean. Personally, I don't think the extra features are worth it of the more expensive models. The EasyClean is great and very simple to use. Buy one, you won't regret it!
  983. Not as expensive as some of the other models, but everything you need. You can program it to beep every 30 seconds to let you know when to switch to a different part of your mouth. Plus, it has some new design features that are quantum leaps above the older styles. The brush just snaps onto the handle, there's no more bulky cap-like thing to screw in. This new design means no gross pond scum growing in the cap-like thingy. I used to dread looking at it, let alone cleaning it out. It's lighter to hold, and the charging base is much smaller, so it's less obvious and takes up less room on the bathroom counter. I didn't want anything too fancy, I didn't need a travel case or a brush sterilizer. All I need for gleaming, whiter teeth is the magical sonicare brush itself, thank you very much. The price is right too. I just wish I had upgraded sooner.

  1015. I bought the Philips Sonicare after speaking with my dental hygienist. I was in for my semi-annual cleaning and saw one on display. I have rheumatoid arthritis (my hands have been compromised for the past fifteen years). I have been using an cordless toothbrush for the past ten years but more recently it has not recharged properly (ten years is a long time). She told me that the Philips was excellent. I looked it up on Amazon and ordered it.<br /><br />As usual my order arrived in a couple days--I've never had a problem with Amazon orders. I plugged it in and let it charge until the green ready light stopped blinking. This toothbrush is sleek and the charging stand is much smaller than my old toothbrush. My first use was a pleasant surprise. The Philips rotates so fast that it makes a high pitched hum. Quadrant cleaning is timed in 30 second increments so it's become easier as the toothbrush lets you know when to hit the next quadrant. When time is up it stops automatically.<br /><br />I've only been using this for a week so I will update if needed. So far it has met my expectations. My teeth feel cleaner--it's like the smoothness you feel after getting your teeth polished. This toothbrush is sleek, the brush removes easily and it doesn't 'gunk up' like my old toothbrush. I've read other reviews about hard bristles but I don't have that problem.<br /><br />I recommend this buy for everyone, more so for folks like me with RA who have difficulty using their hands. My next purchase may be the air flosser as my hands cannot navigate a regular flossing regimen.

It does an excellent job cleaning and my teeth feel like I just left the hygienist's office when I use it. Love the timing feature too, it ensures I don't rush and get to all my teeth evenly. Highly recommend.
  1058. This is my third Sonicare toothbrush, The first was the Essence, the second was the Flexcare. The Easyclean, the current toothbrush I use, is the best of the three. I didn't like the brush head on the Essence and it used NiCad batteries. The Flexcare had features I never used and it lasted a little over a year. It has too many functions which can go bad and they did. Also, the buttons sometimes would get pressed by mistake while I was brushing. They're too close to where you hold the toothbrush. It had a Lithium battery which is far superior to the NiCad of the Essence.<br /><br />The Easyclean is simple, On/Off. I'm hoping that it's simplicity leads to a longer life. It also uses a Lithium battery and it is amazing that it holds it's charge for two to three weeks before needing to be recharged. I used to place the other models on the sink in their charger but not with this model. Everything goes in a drawer and comes out only when needed.<br /><br />Every time I'm finished with the toothbrush, I wipe the brush head with my towel and pull the brush head off and wipe the top of the toothbrush body to keep it clean. It takes two seconds and works like a charm.<br /><br />I believe the Sonicare toothbrushes have significantly helped my teeth and especially my gums over the years. I have had a problem with Gingivitis almost all my adult life. I have to constantly take extra care with my teeth and gums and see my dentist and periodontist regularly. They both highly regard the Sonicare.<br /><br />I have no connection to Phillips and I am angry over the Flexcare failure. I called them to complain and they said there is a two year warranty but that I needed to provide the store receipt. I couldn't find it so, I lose. This time, I registered the toothbrush online to prevent the same issue if it occurs again and they added a extra six months to the warranty to boot.
  1059. I bought this for myself to replace the old one I lost while on vacation, then also one for my husband, my son, and my daughter in law. It does a great job.
  1060. Replaced another Sonicare model with this one. Old one gave good service but had one major fault---allowed disgusting \\"gunk\\" to build up inside the handle. Several of the reviews for this model mentioned a simplified handle-to-brush connection that greatly reduced the opportunities for gunk build-up like they had experienced with various brands/models. For me this was the deciding factor and so far, so good. It doesn't have all the bells and whistles of some models but it covers the basics (and more)quite well. Main thing---it's easy to clean and keep that way. Goodby \\"gunk\\".

The manual says you can leave it on the charging base without diminishing its ability to fully recharge, but I don't. It lasts a good two weeks before I recharge it.   1090. Everything about this toothbrush seems to be wonderful with one exception. Except that in reality, it doesn't BEEP! I called Philips directly, and the cheery woman on the phone explained that it isn't supposed to beep. Despite what the packing and advertising claims. It doesn't beep, it's not supposed to beep, and the company doesn't seem to care that they are marketing a product that does not perform as they claim.<br /><br />Sure it's a very minor issue, you can still feel the pause and it does shut off after 2 minutes. But would I purchase from a company that fails to provide a product as described, and doesn't seem to care? Nope.<br /><br />Shop Wisely.

  1098. I had an Oral B and loved the small, round brush head design. However, the Oral B brush lacked the &#34;sonic technology&#34; that my dentist insisted is superior.<br /><br />Having hated the Sonicare E-series I had years ago, I was pleased to see this new slim design. While the EasyClean's handle is lighter and more ergonomically designed than those of the E-series, I'm disappointed to say that I still find its brush head design to be messy and cumbersome to use if you have a small mouth. Furthermore, the EasyClean stops at the end of the 2-minute cycle rather than just giving an alert and allowing the user to continue brushing uninterrupted if needed.<br /><br />If I had to do it over, I would buy another Oral B. The round head of the Oral B brush allows the user to access those hard to reach spots, like the backside of the front teeth and wisdom teeth. The Oral B toothbrushes also continues to operate after giving a 2-minute &#34;alert&#34; (double vibrate) so the user can decide how long to brush.<br /><br />As for performance, I've used the the EasyClean toothbrush for a few weeks now and it does make my teeth feel &#34;squeaky clean.&#34; That said, I often have to restart the cycle because I feel I have missed spots due to its bulky brush head. Also, at the end of every cleaning, I have to wipe down my mirror and faucet and cabinets. What a mess!<br /><br />In contrast, the Oral B brush glides easily over and around each individual tooth with no mess. Furthermore, while using the Oral B, I have always received high praise from my dental hygienist (no plaque buildup or cavities), even when I went a couple of years between cleanings due to health reasons. This leads me to believe that adding &#34;sonic technology&#34; to my regime won't make a measurable amount of difference.<br /><br />My advice is to buy a basic electric toothbrush that fits your individual preference (round or traditional brush head). IMHO, the &#34;bells and whistles&#34; (whitening mode, etc.) don't seem to be worth the added expense. In my case, because my mouth is small, I wish I had purchased another Oral B.

  1154. Being a dental assistant, I was constantly being nagged by my boss to get a Sonic Care. So with the Christmas bonus I got, I bought this one. The &#34;timer&#34; isn't a beeping noise but a quick break in the vibrations so you know to change quadrants. It shuts off after the two minutes are up. My teeth feel so much cleaner and my hygenist swears I will have a better checkup.   1156. Years ago I tried electric toothbrushes; hated them. My teeth still had that scummy feel. Recently my dentist said that I was continuing to brush too hard, thus dangerously exposing my roots. She suggested an electric toothbrush. I scoffed based on past experience, but purchased the Sonicare anyway. Wow how technology has changed. Bottom line, I don't have that scummy feel on my teeth and I no longer have the need to apply pressure to the toothbrush. The bristles feel like they are vibrating, yet they seem to push the saliva generated between the teeth. Speaking of saliva, it does generate a lot! I'm still trying to get the proper technique down where it isn't dripping down the toothbrush handle. There's definitely a reason why you don't see these toothbrushes being used by characters on TV and the movies! I like this model because of the timer so that you brush your teeth for 2 minutes (30 seconds for each quadrant). I recently heard the average person brushes their teeth for only 46-47 seconds! I am looking forward to my next dental checkup to see if the staff notices a difference in the health of my teeth and gums.
  1157. I love the philips sonicare toothbrushes. This one's great too! I'll buy again, if I need to. The product is great.
  1158. My son requested this for Christmas to replace his old worn out Sonicare. He hasn't had a cavity since he started using Sonicare years ago.
  1159. I am enjoying this toothbrush that replaced an older version Sonicare. It doesn't catch the debris like the older brush & is a nice size. It leaves my mouth feeling wonderful.
  1160. Disappointed with the poor reception... Radio itself is quality
  1161. This was purchased as a replacement for a ten year old Sonicare with the large head, The smaller head is a great improvement and the replacements are so much less expensive. These are the best of the best and always receive compliments from the dentist on how clean the teeth are.
  1162. I love that the brush does the work. I love getting great checkups from my dentist (seriously!). I love that this version is so much cleaner than the older models where toothpaste and water slime leaked into the brush head. Only negative is that it's so &#34;slim&#34; it's a bit hard to hold when turned on and vibrating. I'll get used to it, I'm sure, but I liked the thicker base of the older model for this reason.

  1169. Before ordering this toothbrush, I had the more expensive Sonicare Plus with the different brushing modes. I never used the extra features and the extra buttons were too easy to accidentally push when you were using it. And it lasted only two years before the battery would no longer charge.   1172. Stays clean; no nasty build up on the brush which was my main concern when looking for an electronic brush. Long battery life. Leaves my teeth feeling nice and clean. The timing mechanism to let you know when to change quadrants is very helpful.
  1173. We bought this to replace our Sonicare toothbrush that was a predecessor to the 5300. It was a little over 6 years old. It was still working great except the battery would no longer hold a charge. This HX6511/50 is an excellent replacement. It's much thinner in design, holds a charge for way more than a week before needing recharging and the brush is now just the brush head. Our old Sonicare was a brush and fat base, a real waste of plastic.<br /><br />This thing was ready to use right out of the box; came with the body, new brush head and a recharger. We read through the directions, put it on the charger overnight and then deactivated the program that gradually increases the \\"power\\". It makes a beep every 30 seconds to let us know to start brushing the next quadrant of the mouth. It also has the two minute shut off. No complaints at all and by using Amazon.com, we got the best deal. I compared with Walmart, the Sonicare factory outlet and other online stores. No one had a better price than Amazon.<br /><br />Just a reminder that there is a small gap between the bottom of the toothbrush and the top of the toothbrush body. I thought I had not placed the brush on correctly, but then re-read the directions and it indicates the gap is intentional. Probably so we can rinse that area.
  1174. I can't believe I went so long without a Sonicare toothbrush! My gums and teeth are the healthiest they've been since I was a child.
  1175. As some other reviewers may have mentioned, the Quadripacer DOES NOT BEEP. It simply pauses before the next 30 second interval and shuts off after 2 minutes. Why does Phillips say it beeps when it doesn't is beyond me. However, it does perform better than any 10 or 20 dollar unit outside of that one mis-advertising issue. The brush also is contoured to get in between teeth as well, which I liked.
  1176. I'm very happy with this toothbrush! Highly recommended! It reaches those hard to get places and works really well! The battery lasts a long time and it's lightweight enough for travel.

After having these for a few months they are exactly what we expected. Every time you brush you will feel like you just got a cleaning at the dentist. Battery lasts forever and the new Pro Results cleaning head is bigger and seems to clean better. This particular model is the cheapest of the new Pro Results Line that has the &#34;Quad-Pacer&#34; function wich makes brushing easy and brainless being that the brush signals you to switch to a new quadrant of your mouth.   1199. My wife and I needed a new electric toothbrush--our Braun was losing usable charge every other day. After hours of research I settle on this model, and I'm elated (as much as one can be over a toothbrush) at my choice. Li-ion battery promises a longer life with more time between charges. 31K vibrations/sec requires some getting used to after our Braun; it tickles the mouth (in the beginning--you get used to it) and emits a very fine mist from your mouth if its open. My wife believes it does a better job than our Braun. We didn't have a top-of-the line Braun, but this is not a top-drawer Sonicare model either. Just the charger (a little more weight would be helpful for stability while charging), the vibrating unit, and a toothbrush--bare bones, but all we need. A great value. I also bought the softer bristled brushes, having sensitive gums, and following the general advice of dentists and hygenists.

  1202. This is my second Sonicare - the first one lasted 5 years - and there seems to be a change for the worse in terms of quality control. Sadly, just a few months after receiving the replacement (which I assume was refurbished) it crapped out in the same way as the original. The brushing &#34;power&#34; was greatly diminished and it made a loud noise. I cleaned it as well as the charging stand thoroughly but to no avail.<br />For $80 I expect the item to last longer than a year.   1205. Sonicare stopped working after 9 months and not exchangeable at Amazon. That makes brushing very expensive!
  1206. I waited four or five months to review this product and will explain why in a moment. I upgraded from Philips Sonicare Hx5351/30 Essence, Rechargeable, Power Toothbrush (copy and paste from order history) and was not too happy with that product. I won't go into it too much but the head allows water inside which causes a grody sort of mildew capture area inside the brush. So, I upgraded to this one because the head seemed to be seated differently and was hoping to avoid that nasty problem altogether. The problem with THIS product--the reason for the review delay--was that the head didn't fit quite fit flush to the handle so I worried about water getting inside. It didn't. There is no opening for which water to escape into, so problem averted! Other than that, the handle is slimmer and more lightweight and seems to need to charge less often. I do not want to make this totally about comparing the two products, so I will say that I do love the slim handle on its own and it does a great job. I have healthy gums and clean, tartar-free/plaque-free teeth (according the my dentist, not just myself). I did not tell them I was using this, they just must think I am going nuts on my own and attacking those cavity creeps on my own. The only thing I don't like, which does not deter from stars, is that it only stays on for two minutes. It's okay, because you can simply push the button again, but I am not sure who is cleaning all their teeth and mouth in two minutes. Overall, great product. Does a great job. Pleased with the upgrade!

I thought two minutes was going to be a tediously long amount of time but it flies by and I usually want to go for longer. The only thing I note is that while it says to replace the brush head every three months, I have to replace mine every two months becasue if I leave them on longer, they start to cut up my gums. I mentioned this to the dentist and he did say that I may be brushing too hard and if the bristles aren't tight enough they will act like razors and cut the gums.... easy fix.

  1283. Design flaw? I've had three of these electric toothbrushes in about 4 years and all have failed. The metal shaft becomes loose inside the body, it gets gradually louder as the vibrating action decreases. After a few months, lots of noise and not a lot of action. Philips replaced two of them under warranty but refused to do it a third time.<br /><br />I'm not abusing this product, don't press too hard, and have been very careful with this third unit. I have to believe this is a design flaw, that it's known and understood by Philips, and they were just waiting out my sequential warranty period(s) to cut their losses.<br /><br />I will not buy another Sonicare and will switch to the Braun brand--which my wife has had for nearly 10 years with the same battery and no problems!

  1295. The Sonicare Easy Clean is very basic but does a perfect job at making your teeth feel clean and look pearly white. I like to have it brush my teeth for me! I bought the Easy Clean after reading many helpful Amazon reviews. It does have the extra feature of the Quadpacer that I really like. At 30, 60, and 90 seconds, you hear a short beep and pause and you know to move to another section of your mouth. There is no travel case but I did not need one. One person commented the brush head was slim and compact compared to the Essence model. At the time, I got a good buy on extra brush heads. The only drawback to the Sonicare is the pricey brush heads. You might want to check around for good buys on this. I think Pro Results standard brush heads fit the Easy Clean toothbrush.

My teeth feel nice and clean, and I find that instead of switching every other day between regular brush and sonicare, I want to use my sonicare every day. I also like the 14 day step up process. Since I have really sensitive gums, this has helped me to adapt to the new brush. For what it's worth, I use a Waterpik brand flosser at night- the two are making a great team so far and although I NEVER look forward to my dental cleanings, I'm cautiously optimistic that my mouth will look and feel significantly better at my next appointment!

  1324. I cannot recommend this product. It did a very good job when it worked, but with a two year warranty, it should not have stopped in less than a year. Philips' customer service policy leaves a lot to be desired. Shipping is 7 to 10 business days, which we all know means at least two weeks. I had to speak with a supervisor because they were only going to send the handle, not the handle and charging base. They nor I have any idea whether it is the handle or base or both. I was told if the replacement handle wasn't the problem to call them back and they would send a charging base. When I explained that would take a month in shipping time, I was told that was their policy. The supervisor did finally agree to send both the handle and charging base. I asked why shipping time was so long when Amazon could have a new one to me in two days, and was told that was how Philips worked. Well, after I hung up, I placed an order for an Oral-B with Amazon and it will be here in two days. Had the Oral-B before and I was very happy with it. When it died, I thought I would try a Sonicare. Not a very good decision on my part.
